PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PETITION.PARA: The United Nations declaration on the elimination of all forms of intolerance and of discrimination based on religious belief:
prohibits all forms of religious discrimination, thus potentially restricting the freedom of Australians to make any choices on the grounds of their belief;
could lead to US-style prohibitions on public Christian prayers, Christmas carols, or nativity scenes;
has the potential, according to the NSW Attorney-General, to restrict greatly the freedom of religious groups.

gives wide rights to children in Articles 12-16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;

could result in Government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the purpose of my private members amendment Bill is to make the Auditor-General an officer of the parliament, independent of the government. This is a necessary step to achieve a proper relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament.

In the United Kingdom, Canada, United States and certain other countries, it is accepted that there is also a relationship between the external auditor and its client, the parliament, for the provision of measures required by the Auditor-General to effectively perform his functions.

In order to reinforce the desire for independence parliament has the responsibility for determining the appropriation of money for the performance of the function of the office of Auditor-General. In terms of its relationship with the government, the office has historically stood somewhere between the parliament and the executive.
While the Audit Office fulfils a very important function in scrutinising how government bodies conduct themselves, its operation has not been free of problems.

There is an inherent conflict between the desire of executive government and its bureaucracies to operate free of constraints, and to some extent accountability, and the desire of those who provide the wealth for these operations, the citizens of Australia represented by the parliament, to remain informed of what those in government are actually doing.
There must be an expert, impartial source to provide auditing of expenditures of government departments and bodies on behalf of the parliament.
In March 1989 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts argued in Report No 296 `The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and the Parliament' that:
a strong Audit Office is essential for the maintenance of accountability of Federal Government organisations and officials to parliament:

the statutory relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament, unchanged since Federation, needed major revision to reflect both the evolution of government over that period as well as the evolution in the role of audit.

The committee, finding that the Audit Office had at best major problems and at worst was in a state of crisis, intended to add meaning to parliament's status as the Auditor-General's client through the establishment of a better foundation for relations between the Audit Office and the parliament.
Two examples of the problems besetting the ANAO were:
[1] resource constraints (Auditors-General Monaghan and Brigden have in the past complained about the effects of this on their independence); and

[2] the fact that the ANAO "most important auditee", the Department of Finance, was the principal adviser on the Audit Office's resources. At present, the Audit Office must negotiate with the Department of Finance in relation to its funding.
The Public Accounts Committee identified five reasons underlying the ANAO's problems, namely:
[1] Parliamentary complacency;
[2] the office fell between the two stools of the legislature and the executive, apparently with neither willing to take responsibility for the condition of the office;
[3] the lack of a mechanism allowing parliament to assume responsibility for the office;
[4] a previous over-emphasis on economy of operation by the Audit Office rather than on re-appraising its contribution to effective and good government; and
[5] a lack of awareness of the importance of the audit of government activities.
The solutions that the Public Accounts Committee sought inter alia were :
[1] explicit re-affirmation of the necessity for the Auditor-General to be free of political control;
[2] a new Audit Act establishing the Auditor-General as an officer of the parliament;
[3] the establishment of the Audit Office as a statutory authority;
[4] the granting to the Auditor-General authority to determine the terms and conditions of the employment of staff.
Needless to say, the parliament still awaits the legislation so revising the Audit Act 1901.

There have been various other sources recommending a strengthening of the Audit Committee's mandate. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has so recommended as has a previous external auditor of the Audit Office, Mr Michael Sharpe of Coopers and Lybrand.

The principle of independent external audit of government bodies of whatever legal form and the reporting of such audits to the Parliament is crucial in assisting the Parliament to operate on an informed and effective basis. It is therefore an essential element of democratic government.

The Auditor-General must not only be free of any influence or control in its audit activities and conclusions it must be seen to be so independent. Constituting the Auditor-General an officer of the parliament would contribute greatly towards this objective.

This bill implements the will of the parliament, as articulated in the Public Accounts Committee report, that the Auditor-General be clearly created an officer of the parliament and so given a vital independence. I therefore urge all members of this chamber to support this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Audit (Auditor-General an Officer of the Parliament) Amendment Bill 1993 is to make the Auditor-General an officer of the parliament, independent of government. In recent years a lot of political commentators have been concerned about the growth in the power of the executive at the expense of the parliament. This bill is an attempt to restore a better relationship between the two. Parliaments in other countries have a better relationship between their auditor-general and the parliament.

PARA.TAB: This was the recommendation of the public accounts committee in 1989, supported by all the major parties. The government has done nothing to implement those recommendations of 1989. Unfortunately, there has been an air of complacency on the part of both the executive and the parliament with regard to the status of the Auditor-General. Support has also come from the independent auditor and from all the inquiries that have taken place in relation to the Auditor-General's office.

Unfortunately, the Auditor-General suffers unreal financial cutbacks which have not necessarily been targeted against the current Auditor-General. In fact, the last three auditors-general in their reports have publicly reported on curtailment of their activities as a result of financial constraints placed on them by the executive.

There must be a strong Australian audit office for the maintenance of the accountability of federal agencies and officials to this parliament. Hopefully, the next step will be a new audit act. In fact, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration recently wrote to the government seeking its speedy introduction into the parliament. I ask for the support of all honourable senators for this much needed reform.

The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 forms part of the package of seven cognate bills which are being introduced today to give effect to the new prudential arrangements for superannuation announced by the Treasurer on 21 October 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 provides a mechanism through which members of superannuation funds can enforce their rights by way of statutory disputes resolution arrangements. There will be a statutorily appointed Tribunal which will make determinations in respect of complaints. The full Tribunal will consist of up to nine people; the Chairperson will be a full-time statutory officer, with the remaining Tribunal members serving on a part-time basis. The Treasurer will appoint the Tribunal members on the basis of their knowledge and experience; two members of the full Tribunal will be appointed after consultation with the Minister for Consumer Affairs. In respect of each complaint, the Chairperson will choose two other Tribunal members to sit with the Chairperson and determine the complaint. These arrangements will provide for continuity of decisions, while achieving a degree of balance, and will apply to all types of superannuation products, including those offered by life offices.

The measures provided for in this Bill complement other measures in the various companion Bills I am also introducing today which together will strengthen substantially the framework of prudential supervision of the industry.
I commend the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 to the Senate and present the related Explanatory Memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, this is a most unreasonable suspension of standing orders from Senator Hill and it is a most unreasonable suggestion from Senator Watson—and apparently we will receive the same from Senator Kemp—to seek leave to speak at this time.

PARA.TAB: The sessional orders of the Senate on this matter are absolutely clear, as is the precedent, as is the way in which this chamber has operated on these matters since the reference of bills to committees orders of the Senate came into being on 5 September 1989—not opposed by anyone on that side of the chamber nor at the time when they were readopted on 5 May 1993. It is worth reminding the Senate of what the key sessional order says. Sessional order (10) says:

That a report from a standing committee relating to a bill referred to it under this order shall be received by the Senate without debate, and consideration of the report deferred until the order of the day relating to the bill is called on.

SPEECH.PARA: There is ample opportunity for those senators who are members of the committee, or any other senator, to address the Senate on these issues. These bills were suspended at the first reading. There is any number of opportunities for Senator Watson, Senator Kemp and Senator Hill—hopefully, it will be limited to that number of senators—to express their views in the substantive debate we are going to have on these matters. That is the way the reference of bills to committees is supposed to work.

PARA.TAB: This motion to suspend standing orders and Senator Watson's proposal to seek leave in this matter are nothing more than an abuse of the processes and procedures of the Senate. It ought to be stressed that this has never happened before. Never before has any senator believed he needed to use this ruse to get up and speak to a committee report. Those opposite talk about an opportunity to speak for five minutes. Senator Hill said that they only want five minutes. There is much more opportunity available than that. To start with, there is the opportunity to make a 20-minute second reading speech.

No reasonable person—and most of them are sitting on this side of the chamber—could come to any conclusion other than that this is yet another opposition filibuster, another attempt to waste this chamber's time. They know that is the case. All they are trying to do is delay the substantive debate. Let us have it. We are willing to have it.

We have been very cooperative in terms of seeing these budget bills debated in the chamber and in the way we have managed proposals—for example, the notice of motion Senator Short has given. But we are not going to ride roughshod over these procedures because one or two senators want to make a five-minute contribution on a matter when they have ample opportunity to do so during the substantive debate on these bills at a later stage. This motion to suspend standing orders is a filibuster; it is a delay; it is an attempt to waste the Senate's time. I urge senators not to support this absurd, ridiculous and time-wasting motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion for the suspension of standing orders moved by my colleague Senator Hill. If ever we have heard a time-wasting filibuster, we have just heard it from Senator Faulkner today. If people want to know why this chamber does not operate in a more effective fashion, they would just have to tune in to this debate.

PARA.TAB: A request was made with a specific time limit. We asked for eight to 10 minutes for two speakers to make some brief comments on an extremely important report. We have already passed the eight to 10 minutes that this debate would have taken. The mishandling that we so often see in this chamber in the management of business has been further demonstrated today by Senator Faulkner's gross overreaction to a very straightforward and reasonable request.

It is a very common procedure in this chamber to seek leave to make brief comments on matters of importance. We set a specific time limit. The arrogance of the government in the way it treats this chamber and the parliament was demonstrated by Senator Faulkner's comments.

The reason we sought to make some brief comments on this report was to make sure that the Senate was fully briefed on a number of vital and continuing issues which emerged from last Friday's hearing. I believe that those assurances were given. I thought Senator Schacht generally acted in a most constructive manner at the hearing, recognising that these bills contained some very real problems.

In relation to the Nabalco submission presented by Dr Terence Gardner there was an assurance that there was a real problem and that a meeting would be organised with Mr Dawkins to deal with the very serious problem of the bauxite producer at Gove. There were also submissions from the shipping people. Mr Payne from the Australian National Maritime Association submitted an excellent submission and again sought further discussions with the relevant minister.

Yesterday Senator Collins said that the matters which were raised by Mr Payne were still under consideration by the government. Senator McMullan may not know that and that is why it is important that these particular points are brought forward in this debate. Officers from the National Transport Federation and the Road Transport Forum raised particular issues and sought further discussions with the government, Senator Schacht, Senator Kernot and the Green senators to bring their particular concerns to their attention.

One of the reasons that I have risen to speak—and I think it is important—is that, having received these assurances from Senator Schacht that he would do his best to facilitate meetings, I have had further contact with one of the groups. TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion for the suspension of standing orders and, unlike Senator Kemp, I intend to speak to the motion. The comments that have been made are not relevant to the motion. PARA.TAB: The reference of bills to a committee via a sessional order is not anybody's preferred option; it was a negotiated agreement between all the parties. We were not exactly happy with it, but we had to cop it. One part of the equation was that the reports come in without debate. That was one part of the equation of a whole balance of items.

Once we start to tear that up, it becomes much more difficult to come to any future agreements. We know that as soon as we come to an agreement, the next day, the next week or the next month, someone will come and say, `Okay, on the basis of that agreement, we want to go a step further'. That is why we are concerned about this. It is not because of the particular matter; it is because of the general principle which has been a continuing cause of concern in respect of undermining every reasonable agreement we come to about the mode of operation of the Senate. We cannot continue to allow every one of them to be undermined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel certain that this did not start out as a filibuster, but it has the real potential to develop into one. Senator Watson has explained to me that he expected these bills to come on earlier. The bills are not coming on because the opposition has requested that they be dropped further down the list. So it is not the fault of the government, the Australian Democrats or the Greens that the order of business is as it is; it is as a result of a request of Senator Short and the opposition.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator McMullan and Senator Faulkner that some order is necessary in this place. We do not have much semblance of order most of the time, but I think it is fair that some order is necessary in this place. What Senator Watson wants to say can be said at the second reading stages of the bills. They have been referred before the second reading stage. If we choose to do this today, then we are saying that every time any senator writes a dissenting report about any bill to any committee we will extend the opportunity to that senator to make comments at this stage of the business. I think that begs the question: why just those who write dissenting reports? Why do we not allow every senator who is a member of a committee who wants to say something the opportunity to do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are actually asking for anybody who was on the committee to be able to speak.

—That is not what the motion says, but I still think that is a problem in terms of procedure. If the opposition looks at this, it could suggest changes to the sessional orders. We have a procedure committee looking at all of these things at the moment. But the fact of the matter is that the sales tax bills are coming up next at the request of the opposition. Senator Watson and other speakers will have plenty of time at the second reading stages of these bills to make the comments that they want to make at the moment.

PARA.TAB: While I am certain that it was not meant to be a filibuster and while it is quite obvious that we have spent more time talking about why we should not talk about it than giving Senator Watson the four minutes—and that always happens when we move to suspend standing orders—the problem is the precedent and the extension of that precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. Dissenting reports are part of the system of checks and balances which are so essential in a parliamentary democracy. All too often in this place we see issues railroaded through. The guillotine process adopted in the House of Representatives is an absolute disgrace.

PARA.TAB: Not all parliamentarians are happy about this railroading of legislation through the parliament. Those budget bills that will have the most significant impact on the Australian economy, and indeed our export income, are the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill.

Why are these bills important? It is because they will wipe out decades of micro-economic reform in many industries across this country. They are particularly destabilising to those industries and people who live in remote and decentralised areas. They will wipe out decades of micro-economic reform to firms and industries in the inland and they will be devastating for coastal shipping and road transport. For that reason I sought the leave of the Senate for no more than four to five minutes to briefly outline the concerns in our minority report.

It is true that we will have the opportunity down the track to debate it at the second reading stage if the guillotine is not called on. But the important point is that the minister has indicated that the government is prepared to negotiate. That is all very well for the government which through various mechanisms—some of which deny the constitutional validity of the proper passage of legislation through linkage processes and other techniques—wants to introduce a degree of frustration. The government will have to alter its agenda, as the minister acknowledged at the meeting when he said that we will have to enter into certain negotiations with the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). The government wants to deny this parliament any opportunity even to speak of the right to change any aspect of that legislation no matter how detrimental it might be to industry and the Australian people. I hope that the motion for the suspension of standing orders put by my colleague Senator Hill will be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not just a question of the eight or 10 minutes that Senator Watson and Senator Kemp mentioned, and it is not a question of what we have to hide, as suggested in Senator Hill's earlier interjection. It is a question of the proper processes of dealing with the reference of bills to committees. As opposition members know, the government goes along with this process with some reluctance, but we have accepted the way in which the system works.

PARA.TAB: Originally this system was to be primarily a substitute for the committee stage of bills. But once again we have accepted that, in a large number of cases and to help the timetabling of the consideration of legislation, many of these references should occur before the second reading stage. In this case it was done before the first reading had even been carried. So I do not think the opposition can say there has not been flexibility.

We acknowledge the numbers in here in regard to decisions concerning references of bills. Therefore, we do not use the numbers in the selection of bills committee to make recommendations on this sort of matter. But one key prescribed process for reports coming back from committees that have considered bills is that, as the standing order prescribes, there be merely a tabling of the report and no debate at that stage. That is very sensible, because the tabling of the report is merely a means of bringing the bill back on to the Notice Paper of the Senate so that its next stage can be proceeded with. There is every opportunity for members of the opposition and everybody else to debate the various matters in the majority and minority reports at that point. There is no need to deal with the issue twice over.

Once again, it is not just a matter of taking eight or 10 minutes to discuss a particular bill. If two opposition members want to have a say, why cannot the rest of us have a say? We were not seeking to take up time at this stage. It does not concern just this bill. It means that, for the first time, there would be a change in the procedure that we have been using for the last three or four years regarding the reference of bills to committees. Senators would want then to have leave to make statements on a whole variety of other bills. It is particularly important that we draw the line at this point and say that we must not set a precedent and upset this process.

I emphasise that we are not talking about normal reports from committees. In such cases a report is brought down and it is normal that a senator moves a motion to take note of the report, which allows members of the committee to have their say and for it to then be adjourned to the next sitting Thursday when committee reports get called on. We are talking about a quite distinct procedure in which bills are referred to committees in order to save time in this chamber. The theory of the matter was to save time in the chamber by having committees deal with bills. There is no point in our having that procedure and spending all our Fridays having committee hearings if we are then to allow the same procedures to take place in here, and then add to them by allowing speeches to be made when a report is tabled.

I emphasise that this process is quite different from the one that operates in regard to reports from committees on other references. It is an important part of the reference of bills to the committee process that the tabling of the report merely brings the bill back on to the Notice Paper of the Senate for further consideration. One will not have long to wait as it is the third item of business for the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the Senate that I agree with almost everything that Senator Watson said, except his conclusion. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 and Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a)calls on the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to:

(i)heed the conclusion of the Coalition and Democrat Senators on the committee with respect to Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 and withdraw and redraft the bill in a form that is unambiguously valid under the terms of the Constitution, and

(ii)desist from the constitutionally irresponsible and provocative behaviour of asking the Senate to consider and pass legislation which four of the eight members of a multi-party committee have concluded is of questionable constitutionality; and
(b)notes with respect to Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993, known as the "Test Bill", that the committee has concluded that the bill clearly deals with more than one subject of taxation;

(c)deplores the Treasurer's decision to present a "Test Bill" containing a mixture of provisions identical in nature to those which, in the committee's recently stated view with respect to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, gives rise to a real and significant risk of constitutional invalidity;
(d)calls on the Treasurer to redraft the bill in a form that is unambiguously valid under the terms of the Constitution; and

(e)again calls on the Treasurer to desist from the constitutionally irresponsible and provocative behaviour of asking the Senate to consider and pass legislation which is of highly questionable constitutionality.

The reason I am seeking to do this now is that the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 and Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993 will not come on for debate for some little time. This is a matter that we believe the government and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) should take note of and act upon in the meantime. In other words, I could have sought to move a motion in these terms when the bills came on for debate in this place, but I suspect—I may be wrong—that the government would then suggest that my course of action was a delaying tactic, which it is not.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its report reinforces the concern that was expressed in its previous examination of the question of constitutionality. In our view, if there is any real doubt about the constitutionality of bills, it is the responsibility of the government to put them in constitutional form in order that this parliament might vote upon something that is likely to be sound. Furthermore, it is in order that whatever legislation gets passed in this place is unlikely to suffer successful challenge, with all the dire consequences to the economy that would follow.

That advice clearly came out of the first report of this committee which was the first consideration of the issue under the government's earlier Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill. The government took that omnibus bill away and redrafted it into some eight different bills. To some extent the government has acted responsibly on the committee's advice. What we on this side of the chamber find astounding is that the government did not go the whole way and put the constitutional issue beyond argument. Rather, what the government has done deliberately is that, first, it has sent back to this place a bill which the government accepts is constitutionally ambiguous in order that it might be tested; and, secondly, it has sent back to this place a bill which at least some members on the committee—the opposition members and the Democrat member—believe is of doubtful constitutionality.

We say that the government is wrong in relation to both bills. The second bill is the government's deliberate so-called test bill. We believe that it is improper practice to deliberately put before the parliament a bill which the government accepts might be unconstitutional in order that it be carried and then tested. We say sound parliamentary practice is to put the bill in an unambiguously constitutional form and then to expect the parliament to carry it on that basis. That is our objection to Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2), the test bill. That is demonstrated by the views of the opposition senators in this committee report.

In relation to the first bill, which I think the government believed was in constitutional form, the advice that is now given to the Senate by its committee—certainly by the opposition members and by the Democrat member—is that a significant risk continues. Therefore, it is our view that both those bills, in the few days that remain before this debate comes on in this place, should be withdrawn and redrafted into a constitutionally sound form in order that all the unsatisfactory consequences that could flow will not in fact flow.

It is not a difficult challenge for the government to put its bills right. I think the estimates are that it might take a couple of hours work up to maybe a day's work. That is not beyond the government with all its expert legal advice to handle expeditiously so that when we do have the second reading debate of the bills in this place, they are in an unambiguously constitutional form. The Senate should be grateful to this committee, under the able chairmanship of Senator Cooney, for its ongoing contribution to ensuring good practice in this place. But I particularly rise to put to the Senate the opposition's argument that the government should withdraw both the first bill and the second bill—the so-called test bill—and redraft them so that they are clearly constitutionally valid. This would ensure that when subsequently we debate the legislation we know that we are voting upon something that in all likelihood is constitutionally valid. That is why I have moved this motion asking the government to withdraw and redraft these two bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Hill which, in effect, would mean that Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 and Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) 1993 would be returned to the government. The government would be invited to redraft those bills so as to put the separate matters of taxation that are now contained in each bill into separate bills. The coalition requests the Senate to endorse this motion because we believe that is the appropriate way to go.

PARA.TAB: The government originally put a vast range of tax matters into one bill. In my view, it was an extraordinary attempt by the government to blackmail the Senate and to deprive the Senate of functioning as a proper house of review by saying, `We, the executive, we who have won the numbers of the day in the lower house, have the complete and utter right to set the budget and therefore to run the country'. It flows that if the Senate has no say with respect to any of those matters, one wonders why the Senate is here. This attempt would simply strengthen the arm of the executive over parliament and reduce parliament's control by reducing the capacity of the Senate to influence the outcome of certain legislation.

The bill was referred to the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee, the members of which unanimously concluded that there was a real and significant risk that the High Court would hold that that bill imposed taxation on a number of subjects of taxation and would therefore be invalid under section 55.

We had the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in the other place saying that senators have no business considering this matter. We are apparently paid to come here and give no attention whatsoever to whether the legislation we pass is constitutional. The Treasurer seems to think that it is his role and not a function of a house of review to worry about whether legislation is in the constitutional form. I am sure the Treasurer has received the message from the members of the public, the taxpayers who fund this place—who fund senators and their staff—that they think the Senate does have a role, a right and a responsibility to ensure that it does not just pass legislation irrespective of its constitutional form.

Consequently, the Treasurer caved in, despite his froth and bubble and protestations, and redrafted the bills, except for one which was agreed to be a bill to test the proposition at hand, which is whether an increase in a rate of taxation is an imposition of tax. So there is one test bill and the others are intended to be valid. With regard to the test bill, the coalition does not think it is appropriate that the Senate be asked to pass a bill which it is agreed is of doubtful constitutional form. We especially do not think the Senate should ever contemplate doing that when the option of putting it into constitutional form is such an easy one to take.

Pat Brazil, the former Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, gave evidence to the committee that a very competent draftsman would take half an hour or less to put that original omnibus bill into constitutional form. Only recently the committee was advised that to put each of the two bills we are now discussing into constitutional form would most certainly be less than one day's work for a competent draftsperson.

The situation is not, as the Treasurer would have us believe, that there is some sort of nightmare happening in the Senate, that the Senate is trying to block the budget or anything like that. We are only talking about a number of bills, in any event. What we are trying to do is ensure that they are put in unambiguously constitutional form.

It is obviously true that if this Senate passes a bill which is unconstitutional—or possibly unconstitutional, to put the most positive light on it—that matter may well then be tested in the High Court and it might resolve that question. But we have the Treasurer and the Prime Minister going on television nearly every day referring to people here as unrepresentative swill—despite the fact that they have been elected on proportional representation, which one might argue is a more representative form than that by which the Prime Minister himself was elected—and basically saying that the uncertainty surrounding the outcome of the budget packages is destabilising the Australian economy.

If the proposition the government puts in that respect is correct, then there is a simple way to ensure that certainty: do not leave this doubt hanging over the test bill at all; withdraw the test bill, separate the two subjects of taxation, ensure we have constitutional certainty as to its validity and let the Senate deal with the matter as it will. Then we will resolve the matter quite speedily.

The government cannot have it both ways. The government cannot be saying day after day, `We can't have the Senate dealing with these matters. All of the kerfuffle about this is causing concern', and then in the same breath come forward and say, `But we're going to devise a test bill, whip it up to the High Court, wait a couple of months and see what the outcome is'.

I understand that the taxes referred to in the test bill do not come into operation until a later date, but the point being made by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister is that the financial markets want to know the outcome of this budget and they do not want to wait until after a High Court decision. If what the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are saying is true, the financial markets want the outcome of the budget to be resolved as speedily as possible.

The way to do that is to not fiddle around with test bills. The way to that is—having got the greater numbers in the lower house and, therefore, forming the executive—to put the propositions that you rightly want to put as part of the budget, put them in separate bills in unambiguously constitutional form, and see what the Senate thinks of them. That option is available to the executive; it is an option which would be available with less than a day's work.

All this brouhaha and bleating through the media about obstructionism in the Senate is, in fact, of the government's own choosing—of the government's saying that it has the political right to package these bills as it will and to test things out in the political arena. That is of course right—it does. But if that is the way the government wants to play it, then it should not blame the opposition for joining in that game.

If, on the other hand, the government simply wants to get its budget passed as best it can and it does not want to play politics with the budget—because that is the claim it has been bleating about on television—then it should put the bills in unambiguously constitutional form and give it a go. That is what we say in relation to the test bill. Those arguments equally apply to the first taxation deficit reduction bill which it is not agreed by the government has any constitutional doubtfulness about it at all. Those arguments apply and I will not repeat them.

In conclusion, it is worth pointing out why we say with respect to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 that there is constitutional doubt. Members of the public may well find it extraordinary that up until now the plain meaning of the constitution—the meaning as if someone in the street picked it up and read it—has not been applying; namely, that an increase in a tax rate, which means that people in the gallery are going to pay more, is not regarded in this place and, government senators would argue, would not be regarded by the High Court, as an imposition of tax.

People in the gallery and members of the public who will have less money left to spend because they are going to be paying more tax in one way or another, find that extraordinary. If they are paying more tax, they think extra tax has been imposed. I do not think you would get very far in the front bar of a pub running the argument that an increase in a rate of tax somehow does not impose additional burden and tax. That is what it is all about. I understand there are fine legal distinctions to be drawn here, but that is really the nub of the argument. How far can we take some of these subtle distinctions before we end up being in an absolutely absurd situation?

The query with respect to this first bill, which the government thinks is constitutionally valid, relates primarily to credit unions. Credit unions at the moment pay tax at the rate of 33 per cent on a very small portion of their income. What the government is seeking to do by a number of clauses within this particular bill is take away the exemption from paying tax on a wide variety of income; that is, to say to credit unions, `You are now going to pay tax on a much broader share of your income than you ever have before'. Then it will introduce a new regime of tax at a new rate of 20 per cent.

So the credit unions, which have been paying tax at 33 per cent on a very small portion of their income, now find, if this bill is passed, that they will be paying tax at 20 per cent—lucky them, a lower rate—but on a much bigger portion of their income. The government says, `Don't be silly. We are reducing the rate of taxation. You can't call that imposing tax'. And the credit unions are entitled to say, `Look, get lost. We will be paying much more tax if this legislation is passed. That is an imposition of tax by the combination of those clauses'.

That is what the government is doing. It is imposing more tax on credit unions. We say that there is some strength to that argument—sufficient strength to say that the culmination of those clauses may well be regarded by the High Court as imposing taxation. If the High Court were to say, `Yes, this is imposing taxation on credit unions', the other clauses in the bill that relate to other subjects of taxation, fringe benefits tax, Medicare or whatever—it does not matter—would necessarily fall over because one can deal with only one subject of taxation when one imposes tax.

On a much broader view of what is an imposition of taxation than the one I have just put, namely, increasing a rate or imposing a tax where one did not exist before, one might argue that other clauses in that bill also would amount to an imposition, in which case the whole lot would fall over. Briefly, that was the argument that we put in relation to the first bill. Therefore, this bill, as much as the second bill, has this constitutional doubt over it.

We are not trying to delay things here. We are not trying to cause trouble. People on the other side can resolve this matter with less than a day's work. Take both of these bills back and redraft them. Put the separate subjects of taxation into separate bills. If the government does not want to play politics with the budget, bring them back here and have each of the measures considered on merit. But if the government does want to play politics, if it wants to fiddle around packaging things up in doubtful constitutional form, it should wear the blame for that itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I think this is the second time I have got up before you to speak. On the last occasion you looked so used to the chair, I had not realised that it was your first time there. I congratulate the Senate for putting you there.

PARA.TAB: Much of what has been said already is true. For example, Senator Vanstone has said that it would be a comparatively easy task to redraft these bills. In other words, it is possible for the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) to be taken to the very competent parliamentary draftsmen and redrafted very quickly. As has been said, that would solve any constitutional doubt.

It is true that some very eminent silks have cast some doubt on the way the bill has been drawn. It is also true that the High Court, contrary to what had earlier in the century been thought to be the case, is prepared to apply section 55 of the constitution, as illustrated by the Mutual Pools case and by the Air Caledonie Internationale case. So much of what has been said opposite is true.

It is a very seductive suggestion that the problem can be solved simply by redrafting the bill, but there are matters that have to be put against that. I will start by talking about the constitutional balance between the Houses and what the Houses and the High Court can do.

The problem arises because of the way the constitution under which we all live has been written, in particular, sections 53 to 57. Those sections set up a process whereby the tensions that may exist between the two houses—that is, the House of Representatives on the other side of the hall and the Senate—can be adjusted. It is very much left to political play as to how matters will be resolved. If, indeed, the two houses cannot agree, the ultimate sanction is that we go to a double dissolution and come back here with a new parliament.

Into this context, which was set up by the constitution to allow political play between the parties and between the chambers, came section 55 which required—and I think `required' is the proper word, too—the High Court to decide an issue that was raised before it. Firstly, it had to decide whether laws which imposed taxation dealt only with the imposition of taxation or whether they dealt with other matters as well; and, secondly, whether a law imposing taxation dealt with one subject of taxation or not.

What the constitution has done is create problems which I think may not be properly resolved if we take what, in my view, is the seductive answer which has been offered by the opposition. If we in this chamber, in this parliament, pass our legislation, having regard, as we have at the moment, to what the High Court might possibly say, we will be very much confined in what we do and we may not be exercising the powers that we should be exercising.

That proposition has not only occurred to me, but also it occurred very much to some of the great founding fathers who wrote this constitution. As an example I quote from Mr Isaac Isaacs, as he then was, the Attorney-General for Victoria, who was attending the convention debates on 8 March 1898 in Melbourne when this issue of what was later to become expressed in section 55 was raised. He was answering a comment from Mr Holder who had said:

SPEECH.PARA: A measure—
that is a taxation measure—
would be valid while it was a Bill, and invalid when it became a law.
He was talking about a technical issue that is still in the constitution and which is not pertinent to the present debate. Mr Isaacs had this to say:
That is a very terse and correct way of putting it, and it proves the absurdity of the provision.
He opposed the provision which is now section 55 but lost the debate on that. He then made the comment:
We are, in my opinion, making the Senate too strong a body. To allow these matters to be carried into the Supreme Court—
which was later named the High Court but in 1898 was referred to as the Supreme Court—
is to say that the Senate cannot protect itself, and that the states cannot protect themselves. Surely that is not to be thought of for a moment.
This is the part I want to emphasise:
We want a people's Constitution, not a lawyers' Constitution. We shall be making the Supreme Court, not the master, but the tyrant of the Constitution, by inserting a clause of this kind.

The point I want to make is that the words that Mr Isaac Isaacs, as he then was, become quite prophetic to the present situation. We are now legislating on tax bills which, as Senator Vanstone and Senator Hill have said, are vital to the future good of this country, looking over our shoulders at what the High Court might do. What we are doing is trying to predict what the High Court might do rather than looking at what is good for the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: What this side of the chamber might say is for the good of Australia is obviously quite different from what the coalition and the Democrats might say is for the good of Australia. But instead of debating that, or talking about the best way of structuring this budget, the best program and the best form of policy to put forward, we are debating what the High Court might do. We should be debating what we should or should not be taxing.

If Senator Ellison, in his inimitable and very skilled way, were to get up and say, `Look, you should not be taxing at that rate', or, `You should be taxing something else', the debate would flow across the chamber on the basis of what people thought was appropriate for Australia as a whole. But we are not doing that. This very debate illustrates that we are debating what the High Court might do. Because we are fearful of what the High Court might do we may be confining the very powers that we should be exercising

The words of Sir Isaac Isaacs are quite true: in the present circumstances, we have a constitution which is not a people's constitution but a lawyers' constitution. We are not arguing as representatives of the people here today, we are arguing about what lawyers have told us might happen before the High Court.

We have to take into account what might happen with a bill that may contravene section 55. Clearly, if some bills are written in such a way that there is a very great chance that they will contravene section 55, they ought to be redrafted. I am not saying for one minute that we should ignore section 55, but there comes a time when we should not take any risk that might be presented to a bill which stops us from properly legislating, from properly drawing up a bill, that seems in the best interests of the people.

I would not mind for one minute if the debate were that, because of the political situation, something should not be in this bill, that it should be in another bill. That is fair enough. But it is a matter for concern when we get to the position that we are in now where we cannot structure a set of legislation or debate it as we should because it might be affected by the High Court.

The High Court has the duty to apply section 55 if it is there, but the High Court itself is conscious of the sorts of things that I have been saying. Things become clearer if we look at what is called the `second fringe benefits tax case', the State Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Others and the Commonwealth of Australia, in which a judgment was handed down on 2 September 1987; it has been around for a while so we should know about it. The Chief Justice, Sir Anthony Mason, Justice Wilson, Justice Dawson, Justice Toohey and Justice Gaudron said this about the legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: The foregoing survey of the legislative provisions is destructive of any idea that Parliament has sought to impose a tax on fringe benefits provided by an employer to an employee and has then sought to impose tax on a separate subject or separate subjects of taxation outside that area.
When they talk about `separate subjects of taxation', they are talking about the provisions of the constitution which use that expression. They continued:

Clearly enough the legislation has been framed on the footing that there is but a single subject of taxation, formulated according to a broad conception of what constitutes fringe benefits. That conception embraces benefits, not being salary and wages, referable to the employment relationship, whether provided by the employer or not and whether received by the employee or not. So understood the legislation presented for the consideration of each House of Parliament a "unity of subject matter" rather than distinct and separate subjects of taxation.

The High Court went on to say that, if there is any doubt about it, the High Court should give credence to the way the parliament goes about the action. The High Court says that it should, unless it is quite clear on the face of it, give effect to what the parliament wants.

PARA.TAB: We are not taking up the High Court's suggestion that credence has to be given by it to what the parliament says. Rather, we are saying, `We think the High Court might say this; therefore we will go about a task in a particular way'. Page 344 of the judgment states:

Although the Court is bound to insist on compliance with the requirements of s. 55 so that the section achieves its purpose of enabling the Senate to confine its consideration in each case to a taxing statute dealing with a single subject of taxation, in applying the test stated above, the Court will naturally give weight to the Parliament's understanding that its Tax Act deals with one subject of taxation only. This is because the application of the test involves what is in substance a question of fact or value judgment. The Court should not resolve such a question against the Parliament's understanding with the consequence that the statute is constitutionally invalid, unless the answer is clear . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It is as clear as burning daylight that this issue is not clear in relation to the remarks made by Senator Vanstone. The High Court is saying that it will not put such strictures on the parliament that it cannot legislate properly.

PARA.TAB: We can take the instance that was given by Senator Vanstone about the tax that credit unions have to pay. The High Court has said—whether this is within the general use of language or not—that if one removes an exemption, in this case from a credit union, which it had up until that time enjoyed so that it now has to pay tax where it did not have to pay tax before, that is not imposing tax within the meaning of section 55. In common parlance we might say, `Yes, that is imposing tax', but the High Court has said that that is not the imposition of tax within the meaning of section 55.

The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 removes that exemption so that credit unions become liable to pay 33 per cent tax. If that was all it did, there would be no doubt, on the basis of the High Court authority, that that was not an imposition of tax. But the same bill goes on to say that, instead of having to pay 33 per cent tax, the credit unions will have to pay only 20 per cent tax. So even though it is excused from paying 33 per cent, it will have pay 20 per cent. It is said that that is the imposition of a 20 per cent tax, even though if the credit unions had to pay 33 per cent tax it would not have been, according to the High Court, an imposition of tax.

This issue is open for dispute. People on my committee, including members of the coalition and Senator Spindler, for whom I have great respect, have found that that is an imposition of tax. They probably took into account what the High Court said, which was, `Members of the Labor Party might not think that applying 20 per cent instead of 33 per cent is the imposition of a tax, but we do'. I can understand that. If there is that doubt, then what weight is given to the statement of the High Court that it will, when deciding these unclear issues, give weight to what the parliament itself does? That is the issue.

The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1), which is under challenge here, does not impose taxation on the credit unions. It removes an exemption from paying 33 per cent, which is not an imposition of taxes, according to the High Court, and confines the tax rate to 20 per cent. The High Court has said that if one imposes income tax as an entity and then adds to that category capital gains tax—so that capital gains tax is subject to income tax—that is not an imposition of tax.

The other point raised in respect of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) was that the fringe benefits tax was increased by taxing excess travelling allowance. It is said that that is an imposition of tax. Again, that is not in accordance with the general thrust of what the High Court has said so far. The interesting thing is that all but one of the people who gave oral evidence to the committee in respect of Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) and Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) agreed with the proposition that the increase in the range of the fringe benefits tax was not an imposition of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one of those people didn't work for the government. All the others work for the government.

—I will come back to what Senator O'Chee has said in a minute. All those who gave evidence, except one, agreed that the application of tax to the credit unions was not the imposition of tax. With respect to what Senator O'Chee just said, the evidence given by people from the Attorney-General's Department and the Office of Legislative Drafting is to be ignored simply because these people are employed by the government. I think that may be the problem we have in this case.

PARA.TAB: Government senators—I can speak only for them; I am not speaking about what happened with the coalition or Senator Spindler—gave credence to all the people who appeared before the committee. They examined their evidence. The government senators, at least, thought that those people who were in the government service and those people who were brought in from outside gave evidence to the best of their ability with integrity and honesty.

I am making the same point on behalf of the members of the committee. I would have thought that Senator Spindler, Senator Ellison, Senator Vanstone and, I would have hoped, Senator O'Chee would agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hope so too. I certainly feel that the witnesses were of high stature and impeccable integrity.

—I thank Senator Spindler. One problem with this whole matter is that each lawyer who gave evidence has been attacked by those who have contrary views, which is most unfair. The Senate's proceedings are being broadcast today, so I ought to state on behalf of the committee—I trust this includes all committee members—that it was assisted by all the lawyers who gave evidence. We thought that they gave evidence properly, conscientiously and with great skill. But the position is that, at the end of the day, there has been a difference between members of the committee.

PARA.TAB: One problem in the earlier bill, which has now been withdrawn, was whether or not the increase in the rates of taxes was an imposition of tax within the meaning of the constitution. That question has never been directly decided. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has withdrawn that bill and put in this new set of legislation, which accommodates that. The new set of legislation is in keeping with the way that taxation bills have been drawn up since soon after federation.

In my view, the problem we as a Senate face is that the proposition of our simply withdrawing the present bill, Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill No. 1, and rewriting it because that would be a simple thing to do, symbolises an attitude in this chamber which should not exist. That attitude says that we should allow the High Court to run us rather than the other way around. It is not the sort of proposition that the High Court would seem to agree with, given its decision in the second fringe benefits tax case. I have the greatest respect for the High Court and the ability of every judge on it. It is not as though we are putting ourselves against the High Court, but if we go down this path we are pursuing a dangerous course as predicted by Mr Isaac Isaacs, as he then was.

The structure of tax legislation is very important and should not be disregarded. A government which has a duty under the constitution to bring in a budget is obliged to structure legislation in the way that it thinks best. Clearly, since elements of the budget are all interlinked, it is important that they be linked in the best way. Therefore, to simply say that there is some doubt here and that we ought to change the way that bills are drafted is not to face up to our responsibilities.

If the risk that section 55 might be applied is high enough, things should be restructured. In this case the risk is nowhere near that high under the new regime of the eight bills that have come in. To simply restructure or redraft bill No. 1 on the basis that that would resolve any sort of doubt is not to tackle the issue with which we are faced. The issue is how the parliament is to legislate and what rights it has to deal with legislation that comes before it on its own terms, not on the terms of what might or might not be done in the High Court. The parliament should write its legislation in a way that is for the benefit of the people of Australia generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion proposed by Senator Hill which in essence requests the Treasurer to withdraw the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bills Nos 1 and 2 and to have them redrafted so that their constitutional validity is beyond doubt. The Australian Democrats support Senator Hill's motion to the extent that it applies to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1). However, I will be moving an amendment to delete paragraphs 2(b), 2(c) and 2(d) of the motion which relates to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2). I will advert to the reasons for our position on both matters shortly.

PARA.TAB: I wish to put on the record again, as I did in an interjection while Senator Cooney was speaking, that the witnesses before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, without exception, put cases to the best of their abilities and on the basis of their professional knowledge which was not, in any way, in my considered opinion, tainted by either their employment situation or any other political considerations. I will read into the record the relevant paragraph which was contained in the first report of the committee, which related to constitutional aspects of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. Paragraph 1.3 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee puts on record its view that though it was faced with a range of opinions from highly qualified, highly competent and experienced men and women, they all gave an honest, candid and independent appraisal of the constitutional validity or otherwise of the bill.

I believe the Senate should take note of those remarks. I dissociate myself strongly from the comments that Senator O'Chee saw fit to make and any other aspersions that have been cast in the past. I regret to say that such aspersions have also been cast by the Treasurer on the integrity of the advisers and witnesses appearing before the committee.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the substance of the argument. In my view, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.1) very much challenges the arguments, the evidence and, in fact, the conclusion that was arrived at in the first inquiry of the committee relating to the constitutional aspects of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. The bill contains two constitutionally doubtful provisions, and I believe there is no reason to depart from the conclusion reached by the committee in its first hearing that there is a `real risk which is significant' that the High Court could invalidate the bill. Clearly that risk remains.

The two provisions relate to the taxation of credit unions and the creation of a new class of fringe benefits tax on excess domestic travel. It is quite clear that, in the case of credit unions, the provisions which provide that the tax exemption is removed and the new tax is to be levied must be read together.

I have a lot of respect for Senator Cooney's legal acumen. But I regret that I find it rather difficult to understand how one can put the argument, virtually based on a suspension of time, that one clause removes the exemption and, therefore, because the exemption has gone, the liability jumps to 33 per cent tax and that another clause, just six clauses further down, then says that the tax to be imposed is 20 per cent. I fail to see how we can do other than read those two clauses together as being the mechanics of imposing a 20 per cent tax liability where previously there was none. I believe that this part of the bill relating to credit unions very clearly increases the rate of tax. Therefore, on one reading of statements made by the High Court in various judgments, it would be held to be imposing tax.

If that were the only clause under doubt, it would follow that this clause plus others which relate to income tax would stand, whereas the other clauses dealing with other matters would fail. However, we need also to advert to the second clause, which extends the incidence of tax. The argument here was pushed a lot less forcefully, I must admit. I think one is forced to fall back on the commonsense interpretation that if a particular provision in an act imposes tax on a group of people previously not subject to it, then it must be read as such.

The problem is that there is no direct High Court decision on either of those cases. Witnesses before the committee were reduced to the need to interpret statements by the High Court which were almost obiter to obtain some sort of backing for the case they were putting to us. That introduces the element of uncertainty, which I believe the government is trying to remedy in the medium to long term by introducing a the No. 2 bill as a test bill.

When the committee dealt with the first bill and all its components, its opinion was that it is quite clear that that risk still remains, with two consequences. One of them involves the obvious dislocation of financial markets, people's financial liabilities, the tax that is levied on purchases, and the need, if the bill were to be invalidated at a later stage, for adjustments to be made retrospectively, if possible—although it is acknowledged that in many cases it is not possible. In terms of Senator Hill's motion, I think it is reprehensible that the government put before the Senate legislation which carries with it a very real risk of being invalidated at a later stage.

The other consequence which Senator Hill does not advert to in his motion is that the Senate may well feel constrained in its efforts to deal with each subject of taxation on its merits and that its hand might be forced into accepting a provision simply because it is part of a package—which also contains the lifting of the threshold for the purpose of Medicare contributions—that would be welcomed by the community, and that the Senate may wish to pass and not to delay in any way whatsoever. This is clearly a political strategy. It has been admitted to be such by Senator Gareth Evans in the Senate and by the Treasurer in various media statements.

I think it raises the question of whether the government is complying with the spirit of sections 55 and 53 of the Constitution as drafted by our founding fathers. When one looks at the debates, one finds it is quite clear that they were concerned that the Senate be not constrained in any way from considering individual pieces of legislation on their merits. It is for that reason that we have the prohibition on `tacking' onto taxation measures other matters or more than one subject of taxation.

It is for that reason that the Australian Democrats will support that part of Senator Hill's motion, paragraphs 1(a) and (b) and the general statement 2(a) adverting to the content of bill No. 2, which addresses this question. In fact, the dissenting view that I put on record in the report asks for precisely that—that the Treasurer withdraw the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) and redraft it in three parts to excise the credit union part and have it as a separate bill, to excise the excess domestic travel allowances portion and make it a separate bill and then have the remainder as a separate bill.

I turn now to the question of whether the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) should also be withdrawn and redrafted or whether it is legitimate for the government to put forward a test bill admitting as it does that its constitutional validity is in doubt and that it could be challenged. In fact, there is a challenge to challenge it so that it may be brought before the High Court and its validity determined once and for all. The suggestion made by Senator Hill that this is an inappropriate course of action, that the government should in no case place before the Senate a bill that has doubtful constitutional validity, is one the Democrats do not accept. I believe it is imperative that we have certainty.

The committee has had a number of inquiries, we have had a lot of work done, with a lot of expense and we have not been able to come to a definitive conclusion. I believe it is perfectly legitimate for the Senate to create a situation which will give us certainty through a High Court judgment. It would be better if we could ask for declaratory opinions, and that is a matter we might take up at a future stage; however, in this case that option is not open to us. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraphs 2(b), (c) and (d), omit the paragraphs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should begin by saying that I do not intend to address this issue in a legalistic manner but rather try to address some of the risks and some of the politics surrounding it. I think the opposition has been a little mischievous on this issue. If we review the history, I think we can see that there is an attempt to delay and frustrate the proceedings of the Senate in properly dealing with the taxation bills on their merits.

PARA.TAB: The first report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs dealt with the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. That committee had extensive hearings, received evidence and provided a unanimous report, which has been the subject of much publicity and debate since.

I think it is important that we refresh our memories as to what that committee's findings were. The first finding of the committee, which is often overlooked, is that this is a matter that can only be determined by the High Court. It is important that people remember that because a lot of people have sought to put themselves in the position of interpreting what the High Court may or may not do. But in the end it is a matter for decision by the High Court.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the minister agree with the then Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, Mr Whitlam, when he said on 25 August 1970:

QUESTION.PARA: Let me make it clear at the outset that our opposition to this Budget is no mere formality. We intend to press our opposition by all available means and all related measures in both Houses. If the motion is defeated, we will vote against the Bills here and in the Senate. Our purpose is to destroy this Budget and to destroy the Government which has sponsored it.

Does the minister repudiate this explicit determination of the ALP to tear an entire budget to pieces? Does he concede that Mr Whitlam was right in his unequivocal advocacy of the right of the Senate to block budget measures? How do these statements square with the continued denials of the power of the Senate by the government's petulant Prime Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Gough Whitlam was responsible for a lot of quixotic statements in his time. I think on this occasion he was obviously tilting at a windmill because from my recollections of 1970 he did not quite have the capacity to deliver on the rhetoric that was then uttered. Political rhetoric being what it is, sometimes people say things that can be taken out of context some years later—as Senator Alston just has—with results that, I think, need not trouble us today.

PARA.TAB: What perhaps ought to concern us today is some of the nonsense that has been talked by the opposition, including the arithmetical nonsense that was talked by the opposition yesterday. I have had occasion since yesterday to check the opposition's figures. The truth of the matter is that the 1981-82 wholesale sales tax measures that were dealt with in a robust fashion by the opposition of the time did have an impact in that year of the magnitude that Senator Alston has said—1.36 per cent or 1.4 per cent in round figures. That is roughly the equivalent, at least in 1993-94 impact terms, of the current measures—1.33 per cent. I accept the arithmetic as far as it goes.

However, what Senator Alston neglected to tell us yesterday was that when one looks at the impact in the full year, in the out year, and when one looks at what the actual impact will be by 1996-97, it is a $3 billion impact which is, in fact, 2.4 per cent of the budget. As a result, the figures are just totally wrong in the way in which they were put forward by Senator Alston yesterday.

So the point is made that what we are dealing with here is a $3 billion hole in our budget that is sought to be punched by the opposition by the strategy it is adopting on this occasion. Moreover, it is not doing it in the context of a government en route to a $9 billion or $10 billion deficit, which was the situation in 1981-82 when an extra $200 or $300 million hardly made any significant difference, given the kind of strategy of neglect, decay and disarray that was advocated and implemented at that time.

In the context of our budget strategy, which is a responsible one, a coherent one, a carefully crafted one and, moreover, one in which every dollar matters in terms of bringing the budget together, what is involved here is a very much more serious assault, as I said yesterday, on the fundamental integrity of the budget. There is no comparison with the situation as it existed in 1981-82, quite apart from what might have been the case a dozen years before that.
