TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's reaction to the recent Chinese nuclear test, and what ramifications will the test have for the current testing moratoriums by other nuclear weapons countries and negotiations for a comprehensive test ban treaty?

—It has to be said that the news of China's nuclear test explosion which came through last night is very serious indeed, and very disappointing in the light of the kind of policy attitude that China has so often struck in the past—namely, that it is in favour of a comprehensive test ban treaty, nuclear free zones, non-proliferation treaties and all the rest of the crucial mechanisms that have to be put in place and sustained if we are going to produce a safer world than the one we have had in the past.

PARA.TAB: China has been subject to many representations over the past few weeks and months on this subject, including by me directly to the foreign minister, Qian Qichen, in New York last week, in very explicit and direct terms. The President of the United States and others have made equally forceful representations to China.

It is a matter of great regret, again I say, that China seems to have decided that it can simply ignore that kind of world pressure but, moreover, ignore the logic of maintaining a de facto legal moratorium on tests in order to create the environment in which we can achieve, much more quickly than might otherwise be possible, a nuclear free environment or at least a massively reduced nuclear stockpile.

The implications of what has happened are obviously direct and immediate for the negotiations that we hoped would be able to be set in train shortly on a comprehensive test ban treaty. They are direct and immediate certainly in terms of the likely reaction of the other declared nuclear powers and their own testing program. We can only hope that the United States and other countries—and we are making representations to them right now to this effect—will not be tempted by the Chinese breach of the de facto moratorium which had existed to go back to tests themselves.

The implications are also serious for the nuclear non-proliferation treaty review conference which we are leading up to now in 1995, the atmospherics for which are going to be very much determined by the feeling that the non-nuclear powers have about the degree of commitment that the nuclear powers have to creating a very different environment in the future than that which has prevailed in the past. Anything which suggests that some or all of the nuclear powers are going to go on testing and building their weapon stockpiles with the same enthusiasm that they have in the past is creating absolutely the wrong environment in which to seek an extension of the non-proliferation treaty and the wider application of that treaty in 1995.

We have been unflagging in our commitment to all these instruments, negotiations and treaties; we will continue to be so. I simply hope that sufficient international pressure can continue to be sustained against defaulting countries in this respect to ensure that the environment in the future is a little better than it is looking today.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to his speech on the second reading of the 1981 budget sales tax bills. He said:

PARA.TAB: These sales tax Bills have to be justified by the Government on their own merits. . . The situation may have been otherwise if the Government could reasonably have been able to claim some kind of mandate from the electorate for the significant new burdens being imposed on the community by these taxes. . . What I do mean is that if the Government wants to claim immunity from parliamentary scrutiny of these Bills, if it wants to claim immunity from amendment for them, if it wants to claim immunity from rejection for them, it should have given, at or before the last general election, some broad indication of its intention to rely more on indirect taxes. Of course, the Government did nothing of the kind.

QUESTION.PARA: In light of the minister's remarks, which are an apt description of the current budget tax bills debate, does he agree that the Senate's treatment of these budget tax bills is not just justifiable but fully warranted, or were those 1981 statements of his as quixotic as he claimed Mr Whitlam's comments to be in 1970?

TALK.START.PARA: —In politics, context is all. The context in which those remarks were made in 1981 was a very different context from that which prevails today. We had a government without any pretence to economic credibility or any pretence of having sought to level with the Australian electorate and the Australian community coming into the parliament and seeking to impose a whole new swath of sales tax measures—including on a number of necessities of life, as they were described at the time—which naturally generated the reaction both in the community at large and in the parliament which led to the response of my party and others in the terms that have been described.

PARA.TAB: That was the situation in 1981. That was a very different situation from that which prevails today. This government came into office pledging itself to a program of deficit reduction and fiscal responsibility, making it clear that we would not embark on a program of massive expenditure cuts of the kind that were contained in the Fightback document and the strategy that went with that. We came into government making it perfectly clear, moreover—and this point is absolutely crucial—that, if we did happen to lose and the opposition came to power, we would not be opposing in any way the tax bills that would be put to the parliament by the opposition.

We made it clear that we had a fiscal strategy which was responsible. The details of it were not spelled out at the time, but it was made clear that that strategy involved income tax cuts, that it involved the achievement over time of a deficit reduction of an order of magnitude which was not spelt out in the election campaign, but which, it was made clear, would have to be responsible. We made clear that we were not going to introduce any new indirect taxes. We made clear that we were not going to engage in any major program of expenditure or outlay cuts.

The logical inference to draw from all of that, the logical conclusion to draw from that, for any thinking voter is that we were going to put in place a fiscal strategy that would involve not only income tax cuts on the one hand and no great swath cutting of expenditure outlays on the other, but rather a moderate program of revenue increases in existing areas in order to achieve that fiscal outcome that we described. That was the context in which we went into the election. That was the kind of mandate we had from the Australian community. What we put in place is a budget strategy which is totally fiscally responsible, which is totally what was expected and anticipated by the Australian community and which has been regarded universally as responsible.

That is the particular strategy which those opposite are now seeking to undermine by a program of assaults on this budget, which will result in $3 billion worth of that budgetary revenue side being stripped out by 1996-97. Those opposite are creating an impossible strain on that fiscal responsibility. They are creating an impossible situation for the government by this strategy on which they have embarked. It is not one that is coloured by any shred of responsibility—fiscal, constitutional or otherwise—and they ought to be ashamed of themselves.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the minister's attention to another point that he made in a similar speech. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The final point I make, although it is by no means the least important, is that there is a whole series of precedents in regard to revenue measures in recent Budgets which the Australian Labor Party has voted against in both Houses, without anyone raising cries of inconsistency, hypocrisy or constitutional impropriety.

Do not the minister's remarks in 1981 make an utter farce of the comments that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and other senior ministers, including himself, have made about the Senate's handling of the budget tax bills in 1993?

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a whole string of measures which we opposed in the past. Almost invariably, if we go back through the history of them, we find that they were opposed in circumstances where there was not a snowflake's chance in hell of that particular opposition being translated into any kind of practical impact. As a result, opposition responses were made in contexts which were totally different from that which prevails now. That is the significance of the point I am making.

PARA.TAB: The revenue impact might have been the same in the first year—1.4 then and now—but what we are talking about now is a much more substantial revenue impact—almost double that, and, five or six years out, a $3 billion hole in the budget. The fact that the opposition is prepared to make such an assault implies a scale of fiscal irresponsibility on its part which was never matched by us, even in our most quixotic moments in the past. Again, the opposition ought to be ashamed of itself for seeking to draw the parallel.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade with the United States of America

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and it relates to 1993 and the future and Australia's trade promotion efforts with the United States, a particularly important market for Australia. Is it true that there has been significant growth in the export of elaborately transformed manufactures to the United States? Does this suggest a change in marketing opportunities in the United States? If so, what is the government doing to help exporters take advantage of this change, particularly in the light of the anticipated beneficial effects which the North American Free Trade Agreement, NAFTA, is expected to have on the North American economies?

—The United States is our second most important export market. As a consequence, that is one of the reasons why Australia pays particular attention to the Australia-US relationship. It is well known that there are a number of bilateral trade problems between Australia and the United States. They relate, overwhelmingly, to the area of agricultural commodities. However, the overall trade and investment relationship between Australia and the US is substantial and very healthy.

PARA.TAB: There is also cooperation between Australia and the US in the key areas of the Uruguay Round and in APEC. While the government has consistently acknowledged that the implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement may impose costs on Australia as a result of trade and investment diversion, we importantly also recognise the additional opportunities that NAFTA will create in North America. Therefore, the government has moved to position its services in the United States so that Australian businesses are best able to take advantage of the developments that will occur there with NAFTA, if NAFTA gets up.

As Senator McKiernan's question implies, the United States is the second largest market for Australia's most complex manufactured goods, classified by the Statistician as elaborately transformed manufactures. The export of ETMs to the US last year was worth $A1.635 billion, but the most important element is that that market for elaborately transformed manufactured goods is growing at a rate of 12 per cent a year. Australia's major ETM exports to the USA include automobiles, auto parts, office and ADP equipment, aircraft parts, specialist machinery, scientific instruments and power generation equipment.

As part of the continuing push to further improve Australia's export performance, Austrade has now opened three Australian trade offices in North and South America. Austrade has opened a new Austrade operated Australian consulate-general in Atlanta, Georgia—the first new Australian government office on American soil in a decade; a new Australian Trade Commission office in the Detroit area of Michigan to service the export interests in the North American automobile industry; and an Austrade Australian consulate-general office in Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city and the industrial and business hub of that country.

Austrade has also established a partnership with more than 25 Australian-American chambers of commerce across the United States and Canada, aimed at helping Australian exporters plug directly into an established network of American business people. This agreement, reached at the annual convention of the chambers of commerce at Snowmass, Colorado, means that Austrade would now be linked electronically to all private sector Australian-American chambers in North America, providing a vastly expanded network of individuals and businesses to assist Australian exporters operating in that market. This partnership, established on a dollar for dollar funding basis, will give Australia a very efficient and cost effective system of accessing the North American market. It will also position us to take advantage of what trade opportunities arise out of the Olympic Games in Atlanta.

In South America, Sao Paulo, with a population of 20 million, accounts for two-thirds of the economic activity of Brazil and boasts a GDP equivalent to Australia. Sao Paulo will concentrate on telecommunications, automotive components, agricultural technology, English language education and specific trade opportunities. It means, in short, that our presence on the American continent, both North and South, is now enhanced, strategically located and aimed at lifting that trade performance that I spoke of earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Will he accept the Auditor-General's recommendation to relocate both the Kingswood and Newington armament depots to the proposed east coast armaments complex—and not just Newington? How will his cabinet submission on the east coast armaments complex be integrated with plans to relocate other navy facilities and functions from Sydney, given the Prime Minister's strongly rumoured desire to release naval land on Sydney Harbour for civilian development? Will the minister bow to political reality and take Jervis Bay off the list of possible sites for the east coast armaments complex?

—The Auditor-General's findings with regard to stockpiling of ammunition were quite different in terms of Newington and Kingswood. I would be quite happy to abide by the advice from the Auditor-General about Newington. If he had not given that advice, it was certainly my intention to close Newington within the next five years, and I have had that view for three years. That view is reinforced, but not made an imperative, by Sydney winning the Olympic bid, because the athletes' village would be right next door to an armaments complex. In any event, Newington should be closed as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: The problem with Kingswood relates to overstocking, which is now in the process of being rectified. The surplus ammunition will be stored at Bogan Gate in New South Wales. I think in the long term Kingswood will be relocated. I cannot give a time line on that, but there is a large amount of capital investment already in Kingswood; the utility is nowhere near the end of its life. But I think eventually, maybe in 10 or 15 years, Kingswood will be relocated.

The second part of Senator Woodley's question raises the future of the navy in Sydney Harbour. It is my view that the navy will stay in Sydney Harbour for many decades to come. We are following a two-ocean navy policy. So, in any event, at least half the naval assets will move to the base in Stirling in Western Australia.

Those plans to relocate the fleet base, which were announced in 1986 and then cancelled in 1990, remain extant. I have no intention—nor does this government—of moving the fleet base to Jervis Bay. I should also point out that Defence has already released large quantities of land around Sydney Harbour and intends to do so in the future. One would have only to see the plans of the Penguin base, which releases quite a lot of native land for national parks and housing development. The navy has already played a role in releasing prime land around the harbour. When the submarines transfer to Western Australia, Platypus will be closed and disposed of by way of the normal processes, releasing further land for the use of Sydney.

The question of Garden Island is a more complex one, because much of it depends on the future plans of whether the government privatises ADI. Nevertheless, there are possibilities that ADI's current occupation of Garden Island can retract to a core business and release much of Garden Island for the use of Sydneysiders.

Senator Woodley's third question was whether I will rule out Jervis Bay. I will not rule out any of the four or five sites that have been identified until this matter has been considered by cabinet in the next few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the day for Jervis Bay. My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence. Is the minister aware that the New South Wales government is currently considering a range of measures for the conservation of the waters and catchment of Jervis Bay, including the establishment of a marine reserve, a terrestrial national park and a system of wildlife corridors to protect species diversity in the region? Is the Minister aware that there is a potential conflict between these proposals and the proposals by the Department of Defence to relocate the east coast armaments complex, or ECAC, to Jervis Bay? Can the minister advise why the department is considering constructing a munitions loading wharf within the core conservation zone of the proposed marine reserve and an armaments depot and road network which will intrude on the proposed wildlife corridors there? Can the minister advise whether he or his department has been involved in discussions with the New South Wales government to delay the implementation of any conservation proposals for Jervis Bay pending the decisions of the siting of ECAC? The last part of my question has become redundant, as the minister said that he is not wiping Jervis Bay out of consideration.

—I am aware of the proposals by the New South Wales government. In principle, the proposals are not inconsistent with Defence's environmental management objectives for Jervis Bay. The navy has been in Jervis Bay for this century. There is one reason and one reason only why Jervis Bay is in such a pristine condition: that the defence department, via the navy, has been there.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts asked why we would move to that area. I have already indicated to the Senate, in the coincidence of questions that have come up on this, that we have made no such decision to move there. Nevertheless, it is one of the only four viable sites on the east coast of Australia that have been identified.

I return to the real problem. How can we in the 1990s justify transporting ammunition through the western suburbs of Sydney, with a population of two million people, down two freeways and one arterial road, unloading it, shipping it through the middle of Sydney by barge and loading and unloading it on Sydney Harbour? I have previously expressed some shame that this government has allowed it to occur for so long and that previous governments have allowed it to occur over the last 30 years. This is a disgrace. The people of western Sydney deserve something better. Wherever this armament complex goes, the one thing I can assure the Senate is that it will not stay in western Sydney.

The fourth question involves whether I or any members of my department sought to delay any New South Wales government proposals for Jervis Bay. I certainly have not sought to delay them. My investigations, as far as I can take them, show that no member of my department has sought to delay any proposals for Jervis Bay. In fact, every time this matter has come before the federal cabinet, where we have supported a reasonable, proper environmental result in Jervis Bay, we have always put the rider on it that it is subject to finalising Defence's plans to relocate the east coast armaments complex wherever it is to be relocated.

I have visited the Jervis Bay area. It is a superb area. But there are arguments that, if we were so motivated to move the armaments complex there, we would have virtually no adverse impacts, and some positive impacts, on that environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does this mean that the minister would support a full public environmental impact assessment of such a proposal, were one to take place?

—Having looked at the four sites, it is my job to take to cabinet the two preferred sites. The process is then to undertake a full environmental impact study of the two proposed sites. Honourable senators cannot expect a final decision as to the actual site for two years. That is about the length of time any proper environmental impact study takes. Honourable senators can have my assurance that, whichever sites on the east coast are identified, there will be a full environmental impact study.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the minister's repeated assertion that the government will not pass on its dramatically watered down tax cuts and the low income rebate unless all the massive tax increases in other budget bills are passed. Does this mean that the government will, if necessary, be content to allow the original One Nation tax cuts to stand as law, l-a-w? Is the government determined to continue to dig itself deeper into a hole and allow all the nasty and regressive measures contained in the budget to have such a devastating impact on low income earners, and yet voluntarily withhold from them any offsets by way of a $150 rebate? Is this the government's latest outrageous double standard definition of social justice and equity?

—What we are not going to do is engage in a slash and burn exercise of public sector outlays, which those opposite advocate, that will have the most profound adverse social justice consequences of any proposal brought before the Australian people during the lifetime of anybody here. It is clear, and the evidence is unequivocal, that the most profound consequences on social justice occur on the outlays side—that is, the way the government spends its money. That is what the government is not going to do and what fundamentally distinguishes us from the opposition.

PARA.TAB: I certainly have not changed my view that the linkage between the proposals to bring forward the tax cuts and revenue measures to increase the revenue in the budget remains and is economically responsible. Everybody in Australia knows that it would be a more popular decision to give out only the goodies and never make any hard decisions. They also know that it would be irresponsible. Those opposite can try as hard as they like to make us do what we think is wrong, but we will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister mean in his reply that if the massive indirect tax cuts are not passed, then the original One Nation tax cuts will stand, or will the government renege on those as well?

—The best thing about this series of questions is that it makes evident the pain the opposition is starting to feel because of the pressure on its failure to pass the legislation as it should. I make it clear that that is a problem I do not expect to arise, because I confidently expect the Senate, at the end of the day, to be responsible and pass the revenue measures, in which case the government will take great pleasure in paying the tax cuts that it wishes to provide.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the minister advise the Senate of the extent of international aviation growth to Australia for the year ended 30 June 1993? Can the minister also indicate what role Australian carriers are playing in bringing tourists and other visitors to Australia over this period?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that for the year ended 30 June 1993 there was an increase in international passenger traffic to Australia of nearly eight per cent. The total number of inbound and outbound international passengers approached 10 million—that is an increase of over 700,000 on the previous year. This is an excellent result for Australian tourism and trade, particularly when it is considered that it was achieved against a background of difficult international trading conditions.

PARA.TAB: One of the most encouraging features of the results was the increased number of passengers through airports. As I said previously, this is an excellent result for Australian tourism and trade, particularly when it is considered that it was achieved against a background of difficult international trading conditions. One of the most encouraging features of the result was the increased number of passengers through airports such as Cairns and Perth. Cairns airport experienced a 36 per cent increase in international passengers on the previous year. Perth international airport passenger numbers were up almost 13 per cent on 1992.

In relation to the second part of Senator Burns's question, I can inform the Senate that the Qantas market share of international traffic for the year ended 30 June was 39.5 per cent, up two per cent from the previous year—a very good result. Qantas export earnings are estimated to be $2.8 billion in the 1992-93 financial year, making Qantas Australia's fifth biggest export earner.

Qantas currently operates more than 150 flights to or through Asia every week. In the 1992-93 financial year, for the first time ever, Qantas earned more revenue in Asia than in Australia. With Ansett having commenced international services to Indonesia and now having capacity allocations to serve Japan, Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong and Korea, the opportunity exists for Australian carriers to play an expanding role in international aviation, particularly in the vital Asian markets. The importance of these Asian markets is demonstrated by the fact that the Asian region, which currently accounts for around 30 per cent, is forecast to account for over 50 per cent of all international traffic by the year 2010.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the minister whether he agrees with his idol, the former Senator Lionel Murphy—at whose feet he worshipped for so many years—when Senator Murphy told the Senate in 1970 that:

QUESTION.PARA: There are no limitations on the Senate in the use of its constitutional powers, except the limitations imposed by discretion and reason. The Australian Labor Party has acted consistently in accordance with the tradition that we will oppose in the Senate any tax or money bill, or any other financial measure, whenever necessary, to carry out our principles and policies.
Will the minister now accept that the conventions on tax bills which the Labor Party used in 1981 still apply in 1993?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp jumped very quickly over a very key part of that particular quote—that is, that the Senate should act in accordance with limits imposed by discretion and reason. That is the centrepiece of that quote from Lionel Murphy. That is the particular set of standards that those opposite are manifestly totally incapable of observing in this place now or at any other time.

PARA.TAB: Paul Keating is someone who knows about constitutional propriety; he demonstrates that every day of the parliamentary week. Paul Keating made it perfectly clear before the election what he thought was the appropriate response of an opposition when a government has a very clear and explicit mandate for a particular policy strategy. That is what he said we would do so far as the GST is concerned. As much as we hated it, as much as we thought it was bad policy and as much as we thought it was wildly inappropriate for the circumstances of the time, we committed ourselves to vote for it had we come back and been on the opposite side of the parliament.

We did that for the very good reason that that is the only rational way the constitutional relationship between the two houses and between the electorate and the executive can possibly work. We came into government on this occasion with—as I described it earlier in question time—a moderate, balanced fiscal strategy, the elements of which were perfectly clearly laid out to the Australian electorate. It was manifestly clear that we had to go down this particular path. The electorate knew that, recognised that, treated us as a responsible government and voted accordingly. If those opposite have not learnt that particular lesson now, they never will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the Leader of the Government in the Senate has confirmed that there is one rule for the Labor Party and one rule that applies to everybody else. The minister mentioned `mandate' in answers today and yesterday. Could he now do the Senate and the Australian people a favour and point out where in the Labor Party's policy speech during the election period the government said that it would raise fuel taxes, where it would increase wine taxes, where it would raise wholesale sales taxes, where it would place a tax on building societies and where it would break its l-a-w income tax cuts? Where was the mandate for those taxes and where did the government say that in the election period?

—We did not say in the election campaign that we could make black white. We did not say in the election campaign that we could square circles. We certainly did not commit ourselves in the election campaign to unfunded direct tax reductions. We knew perfectly well that we could not have direct tax reductions and the achievement of a long-term reduction in the fiscal deficit without some accompanying indirect tax increase measures. That was the obvious logic of the position we took.

PARA.TAB: What we did say during the campaign, very explicitly, is that there would be no new indirect taxes. We did say that there would be no base-broadening measures. We did say that there would be no new taxes on the necessities of life of the kind that those opposite were seeking to impose. We approached the election campaign and we approach the business of government with exactly that sense of discretion, exactly that sense of reason and exactly that sense of consistency which those opposite totally lack.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I asked the minister a very simple supplementary question as to whether he could tell us where he said he would increase all those taxes.
—Order! There is no point of order. There are too many interjections from both sides and there are too many unparliamentary comments.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the minister aware of the recent finding of the Victorian Administrative Appeals Tribunal in regard to the salary package of Victoria's most senior public servant, Mr Ken Baxter? Mr Baxter's salary package, some $300,000 per annum, has been negotiated under a tax minimisation scheme for senior Victorian public servants—a scheme not available to normal PAYE taxpayers. Under the Victorian government's guidelines for senior public servants, up to half the value of the contract may be taken as fringe benefits. This effectively reduces the taxable component of a public servant's salary by extremely significant amounts. This scheme, if adopted by all state and territory governments, would result in significant taxation loss to the federal Treasury. What will the federal government do to stop this Victorian government tax avoidance scheme?

—I thank Senator Carr for raising the question and drawing the matter to my attention. It is certainly a cause of concern when a government seeks to use its tax exempt status in this way. I am very glad that Senator Carr has asked this question because it gives me the opportunity to outline the policy measure that we have implemented, which will be coming into effect, which will ensure that this unfair use of the tax system will not be able to continue.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the changes that will take effect from 1 April 1994 there was a built-in bias in the system which created an incentive for employers to pay a portion of the salary package of their employees in the form of fringe benefits. This was an incentive which applied with extra force to those who were tax exempt, such as the Victorian government. It is a great pity and a cause of concern when governments seek to exploit those circumstances.

Some employers have turned this practice into something of an art form. As a consequence, the government has found it necessary to act. The Treasurer announced on 16 September 1992 that from April 1994 the FBT will be levied on the FBT inclusive value of the fringe benefits tax and then those payments will be made deductible for employers for income tax purposes. This means that the percentage paid will be higher for those tax exempt bodies and that the tax effective benefit to them of funding in the way outlined by Senator Carr in his question will no longer be possible.

This new practice will mean that the distortions to the remuneration arrangements in favour of payments in the form of fringe benefits rather than salary, which of course have always flowed mainly to the benefit of higher income earners, will no longer apply. It is particularly of concern when it results in a package being presented to a state government employee at such a level by a state government which is attacking the benefits of ordinary Australian working men and women.

It seems to me extraordinary that one individual can be paid $300,000 without adverse effect to the Victorian economy but nobody can be paid leave loading on holiday pay, even if he or shee is a clerk earning $20,000 a year, one-fifteenth of what Mr Baxter gets. The advantage for fringe benefit in those circumstances has historically been greater for employers on low tax rates, particularly for income tax exempt employers such as our friends in the Victorian state government that Senator Carr referred to.

There has been an 18-month lead time between the announcement of the measure and its introduction which we hope will allow businesses time to review their remuneration arrangements and to otherwise adjust in preparation for the transition. I hope those concerned are doing that but if they are not, then the changes will take effect from 1 April next year. If we cannot get cooperative fairness in the tax act, these measures will take effect to enforce a bit of fairness.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the Prime Minister's actions in the other place over the past few weeks in suspending matters of public importance and censure motions and yesterday cutting short question time after 23 minutes and three questions, and with the minister's particular interest in and contribution to international human rights, is the minister concerned that the human rights of the Australian public are being tampered with by the Prime Minister's suspension of traditional rights under our parliamentary system for the government to be questioned for its actions?

—Every one of the steps that have been taken by the Prime Minister and the government in the House of Representatives has had its own explicit justification based on the misbehaviour of the opposition. The reason why MPIs have been suspended and parliamentary time has been devoted wholly to legislation is the impossible set of hurdle deadlines that the opposition itself has set for the government in conducting its legislative program—firstly, the requirement that bills be introduced by 1 October and, secondly, of course, the requirement that they be debated to fruition in order for them to be able to be brought into this place by the second deadline that was set.

PARA.TAB: This has created a situation where there is no alternative for the House of Representatives and the government managing the business of the House of Representatives but to go hell for leather with legislation every available hour of the day. That is the reason why the opposition has had its other privileges, if you like, its other rights, if you like, in terms of the way in which the place operates curtailed—because of the very impossible conditions the opposition has set for the government. The opposition led with its chin and it has to cop the consequences of what it found.

Similarly with the events of yesterday, the government does accept the legitimacy of exposing itself to questions. We are prepared to answer questions from the opposition any time of the day, any day of the week, any month of the year because the way in which those opposite are performing at the moment makes it an easy ride—day in, day out. When they create the kind of cacophonous conditions, when they create the kind of irresponsible babble and outcry and impossible circumstances that existed yesterday, any government of any parliamentary system in the world would be thoroughly entitled to pull the plug on them and treat them with the response that they absolutely deserve. The opposition is responsible for its own misfortunes in this respect and it should not come in here whingeing about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the minister intend to re-regulate union sponsored certified agreements to put them on the same footing as the proposed non-union award flexibility agreements? In particular, does the minister intend to empower the Industrial Relations Commission to determine whether certified agreements pass a public interest test which would require that a majority of employees has given genuine and informed consent, that all employees have been competently represented, that groups such as women, low-skilled workers, immigrants, young people and old people have not been disadvantaged or discriminated against and that wage rises unrelated to productivity gains are kept within a reasonable inflation target?

—I welcome the opportunity to make clear the circumstances with regard to these important issues that Senator Bell have raised. The government is proposing that there will be two ways of achieving formal, enforceable enterprise agreements. One route will be through the existing certified agreement provisions with some changes to widen the obligation to inform and consult employees to be covered by an agreement. The other will be through new provisions allowing agreements between employers and employees.

PARA.TAB: In establishing this new avenue for enterprise flexibility agreements between employers and employees, the government intends that there be a number of important safeguards to prevent workers who do not have the protection of union membership from being disadvantaged in the bargaining. We see a great role for the Industrial Relations Commission in exercising supervisory power over negotiations for agreement involving unions and those involving employees.

The commission's capacity to ensure that bargaining is occurring fairly and in good faith will be specifically provided for. We consider that all agreements should be subject to a no disadvantage test. This means that the overall terms and conditions for employees under an agreement must not, viewed in an overall context, result in a reduction of the employees' entitlements.

Each agreement will have to be underpinned by an award of the commission to provide an appropriate benchmark for the no disadvantage test. For employer and employee agreements, we will also give the commission a public interest supervisory role as an additional safeguard. We do not intend this to inhibit such agreements which the commission will have to consider on their individual merits and we will make it clear that the intention is that such agreements should be refused approval only in exceptional circumstances.

We do not propose to add this requirement to the current tests for approving certified agreements. We consider that unions are better equipped to bargain effectively than unorganised groups of employees and do not need the same level of protection. Employees will be expressly given the right to be represented by a union of which they are members in negotiations with their employer if that union has coverage of their work at the particular enterprise.

I think that goes substantially to the questions raised by Senator Bell. I think it is important that we put those important facts on the record. I welcome the fact that we not only have this flexibility but also have it in a manner which protects the interests of the less well organised and the workers who otherwise might have had some detriment to their conditions. I know that it gets up the nose of some senators opposite that we are going to protect the interests of low income workers and those poorly organised but, irrespective of whether they like it or not, we intend to continue to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Why has the government reduced, without any warning, the tax free operating allowance for Australian Defence Force members serving in Cambodia? Does this mean that members of the forces will have drawn against their pay only to find that they must pay back their debts to the government?

—Normally, personnel matters would be directed to Senator Faulkner but we announced some time ago that we would set up a regime for allowances that had absolute certainty in the future. At various points those allowances will change and they do not always change downwards, by the way, sometimes they change upwards. When there was a government in Cambodia there was always an intention to have a different level of allowances than previously. Change in allowances will only affect, for a very short period, people serving in Cambodia. As Senator Archer will realise from an answer that I gave at question time in the previous week, a majority of those soldiers are redeployed to Australia. I think many of us will enjoy the march-past in Sydney on Saturday when they will be fully honoured for their service.

PARA.TAB: Years ago allowances were set on a case by case basis. There was no uniformity in approach and no certainty. What we have done is put that sort of certainty in and everyone knows now before they deploy what the preconditions are. If, for instance, the danger level changes, the allowances change—not always downwards, incidentally, sometimes upwards. That is the regime we have put in place.

As to the question of whether any pay would not be adjusted and soldiers would have to repay, as I have indicated, this would be a very small amount in these circumstances. One would hope that, if it were for an extended period, our systems normally would adjust very quickly so those circumstances would not occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Can the minister indicate whether an assessment has been made of the AMA's case for further increasing the gap between its own fee and the government's recommended fee for medical procedures? If so, what is the result of that assessment?
—As Senator Chris Evans probably knows, one of the difficulties in making an assessment is in getting data from the AMA to back up the schedule that it has made.
—The President has offered it to you.

—I only wish that offers would actually be replaced by action. Unfortunately, the AMA is very slow in the action department. Nonetheless, I live in hope and, should it come back, I would be delighted.

PARA.TAB: There are two reasons why the AMA seems to justify its claims. The first is that in some way CPI and wage increases have outstripped the medical benefits schedule. That is pretty hard to see as in the past decade the medical benefits schedule has gone up 62 per cent; the CPI has gone up by less than 60 per cent; and the actual index average weekly ordinary time earnings that the AMA has been using, or at least has used this year, has gone up only 54 per cent. So it is nonsense to suggest that we have not kept pace with the CPI or those kinds of indexes.

The other reason that the AMA has featured, especially yesterday in some comments which were made by its president, is this question of practice costs. It is there that we are finding some great difficulty in getting the data that backs up the assessments. In fact, we still have not been supplied with any data, so we cannot verify it. But I look with some scepticism at the AMA's claims.

For instance, it is suggested by the AMA that obstetricians and gynaecologists have practice costs of 49.7 per cent. That is a pretty high amount for practice costs. If we look at the top quartile of obstetricians and gynaecologists, we are looking at almost $300,000 a year for practice costs. That is a hell of a practice! I would be delighted if anyone could ever show any justification for it—but they will not, of course. When we meet in two weeks time, the AMA still will not have backed up those figures. I will be delighted if it has. If it has, then I will certainly come back in and share that information with those opposite.

I think the other point that must be made in answer to the question by Senator Chris Evans is to look at how this again just widens the gap between general practice and specialists. Over the course of the past few years and looking at attempting to restore the role of general practice through vocational registration and through grants made in the GP reform program, the government has set about a path to try to take the lot of general practice and improve it. But this new AMA schedule simply reverses this in favour of a few specialties. For instance, while GP items go up by less than one per cent, specialist surgeon items go up by an average of more than two per cent.

While I did ask at a meeting with the AMA in August for it to participate in the one that we intend to start in November, I still have not had an official reply; I expect it soon.

I think the main point to make is that 79 per cent of all services are billed at or below the government's schedule fee. Doctors give the real verdict on the AMA fee: only five per cent of services are billed at or above the AMA fee. Doctors themselves know it is so hot that they cannot be in it; it is so hot, the great majority will not be in it. But those few greedy ones who are need to be led by the AMA. The AMA must stop justifying the unjustifiable. It must take the responsibility to make sure that doctors do not misuse market power. It has to take the responsibility to make sure that those specialists who cannot see reason are brought to heel by, by and large, a responsible profession of decent men and women.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today I tabled a report from ASTEC, the Australian Science and Technology Council, entitled Research and technology in tropical Australia—summary report. The report has examined comprehensively the development of Australia's north and the role that research and technology might play in the next decade. The report will provide a great opportunity for tropical Australia. It informs the rest of Australia about tropical Australia's cultural and physical assets, its current research infrastructure and its needs. This major report is ASTEC's response to a commission from the Prime Minister in April 1992 to examine research and technology in tropical Australia.

PARA.TAB: To ensure that its report would reflect the views of the people of tropical Australia, ASTEC undertook 18 months of extensive consultation within the region and released a draft report for public comment in May of this year. The council also consulted widely across the whole of Australia. The report analysed R&D on both a sectoral and a cross-sectoral basis to ensure that broader issues are given proper weight. Cross-sectoral issues were examined under three broad headings: firstly, R&D to take advantage of tropical Australia for the benefit of the nation—an opportunity for world leadership; secondly, R&D for a sustainable society in the region; and, thirdly, R&D specific to the environment of tropical Australia.

I would like to highlight just three of the major issues raised by ASTEC's report. They are: strategic planning of research, tropical health service delivery, and research management for the tropical woodland and savanna systems. The ASTEC report identifies a major structural problem with R&D for tropical Australia; that is, insufficient linking of R&D to community, business or national needs, including the ecologically sustainable development of tropical Australia. This is not a new problem.

The Ord River illustrates the need for the strategic planning approach to research planning. Today the Ord River irrigation area is providing out-of-season produce such as melons and bananas to southern Australia. These crops were not envisaged when the dam was built in the 1960s.

The Ord's success today is due to researchers working with an experienced farming business community and research programs being linked to a business systems approach. I was informed that one of the reasons for the success of these out-of-season crops is the completion of the sealing of an all-weather road from this area to the southern areas of Australia so that the produce could be efficiently and quickly transported to the markets of the south.

ASTEC recommends a strategic planning or business systems approach to the Commonwealth government funding and performance of R&D for tropical Australia. Examples of emerging industries which could benefit from a coordinated tropical Australian strategic plan are horticulture and some areas of aquaculture. ASTEC notes that the challenges of ecologically sustainable development loom large for industries in tropical Australia.

Environmental problems stemming from the rapid intrusion into the tropics of temperate zone agriculture and mining technologies are becoming urgent. The report recommends that research management for the tropical savanna and woodland ecosystems requires immediate attention. It suggests an approach that involves both states and the Northern Territory working cooperatively in the management of this ecosystem which is so important to the mining, tourism and agricultural industries of tropical Australia.

Many people living in tropical Australia are in remote areas with reduced community services and social support. The contribution of research and technology to the health of these Australians in tropical areas, particularly those of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage, is identified as a major concern. The report recommends an investigation of research on public health delivery for tropical Australian communities.

Finally, the ASTEC report recommends that a mechanism be put in place to oversee the implementation of the vision outlined in its report. There is at present no regional body with the responsibility for tropical research and technology policy. I intend to discuss this aspect of the report with my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Alan Griffiths, during the coming months.

In reading the report, honourable senators will find that there is a diffusion of responsibility across two states, the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth. I think we need a more concentrated focus to get the outcomes that are so correctly raised by the ASTEC report. I believe that the present regional task force headed by Bill Kelty will give us an indication—

TALK.START.PARA: —I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 6 dated 6 October 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I am at a fraction of a disadvantage because the Table Office is not able to give me a copy of Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No.6, but I suspect that it would deal with the question of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill that I understand was dealt with by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee recently. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee raised a question about the retrospectivity of an aspect of that particular bill dealing with the dairy industry; that is, I understand, that part that amends the Dairy Produce Act 1986.

PARA.TAB: I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the committee's concern about retrospectivity in relation to that particular piece of legislation. The legislation deals with an import offset to an export enhancement scheme for the dairy industry. It is a scheme funded by the dairy industry itself, but it has the intention of enhancing exports without having, at the same time, those export enhancements offset by any imports of the same kind that are introduced.

It has been brought to my attention that the Atherton Tableland Cooperative Dairy Association Ltd in North Queensland has been severely adversely affected by the retrospective element of this bill. The dairy cooperative is an organisation which has for many years exported dairy products. It has enhanced Australia's international standing by earning overseas dollars for its exports. It has exported to Japan and elsewhere.

A couple of years ago the company found itself in some difficulty in fulfilling its export commitments because climatic conditions—namely, drought—had interfered with its supply of milk. It did not have enough milk to make the export cheese that it was committed to sell. The company used its milk supply to make enough of the product to fulfil its overseas commitments, but then it did not have enough product to fulfil its local commitments. So it imported some cheese from New Zealand and used that to fulfil its local commitments.

That was all very fine. The company applied for its export enhancement. At the time of doing this, it looked at the legislation and said, `What can we do?'. It saw that the legislation said, in effect, that if it imported product and then used that product as an ingredient of exports, it had to pay the import offset. So it looked at that. It got legal advice on the legislation as it then was. It then entered into the course of action that it was adopting because the law said that that is what it could do.

As a result of that, the company put itself in a position where it was disadvantaged to the extent of either $67,000 or $87,000. The company should have received an export enhancement of a certain amount, but the dairy industry people or the government people who control this deducted an amount as an offset. So the cooperative found itself in a position where it was $67,000 out of pocket. It was quite sure it was correct because it took advice at the time. It acted on the law as it was at the time and it did so legitimately.

There is a suggestion that the company was out to rort the system, that it had been in this business before, but that is simply not correct. It was not in the business of importing; it had never really imported before; it was not an importer, as such. It simply arrived at this situation where, in order to fulfil its domestic and international markets, it had to import something. It looked at the law, found out what it said and acted accordingly.

It then so happened that someone said, `You're not acting in accordance with the scheme'. It was said that everybody in the industry knew what the rules really were and understood what it was all about and that there had been bits of paper issued over the period which clearly said what the rules were all about. The fact that those bits of paper were drawn by someone who did not understand the legislation does not seem to count.

This is an instance of a company that has read the legislation, found out what it is all about, taken action as a result of it and then found that, according to the industry, it was doing the wrong thing. So it took legal action, set the matter down for hearing in court after a time and was about to proceed in court when it received advice from dairy industry people and the government that the government was going to retrospectively alter this legislation to defeat its claim.
As I said, I have not had the advantage of reading the scrutiny of bills report at any length, although I see it now. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is concerned that exporters will be required retrospectively to pay a charge which may not have been legally payable at the time they imported the relevant dairy produce. It appears that the doubt as to proper imposition of the charge have been so great that the Corporation appears not to have collected it. Accordingly the Committee seeks the minister's advice on the legal basis on which the scheme was administered and the charge imposed. The committee draws senators' attention to the provision, as it may be considered to trespass unduly on the personal rights and liberties in breach of principle 1(a)(i) of the Committee's terms of reference.

I understand that it did seek the advice of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and that the minister has, at a fairly late stage, provided an advice. To me—I do not want to enter into a legal argument—it appears to be pretty wishy-washy and self-serving advice on the situation.

PARA.TAB: I will be raising this matter again when the legislation comes before this chamber. At this stage, I wish to draw the Senate's attention to that aspect of retrospectivity. In doing so, I again congratulate and bring to the notice of the Senate—I am sure this is not necessary—the exceptionally good work which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee does in identifying these sorts of matters, seeking to redress wrongs and to ensure that no Australian is adversely affected by retrospective legislation.

The instance I have quoted seems to be a prime example of the worst aspects of retrospective legislation. At this stage, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy—I see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) is here—to look at the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report and consider some of the matters that I have mentioned in relation to the Atherton Tableland Cooperative Dairy Association to see whether, in this instance, that retrospective element of the legislation is wrong and really should be looked at. Perhaps the minister or the parliamentary secretary will be able to look at it with a view to in some way assisting the Atherton Tableland cooperative in the predicament in which it now finds itself.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As vice-chairman of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the committee's 56th general report, which deals with the activities of the committee during 1992, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a very busy year for the committee. In fact, 29 public hearings were held at a variety of locations, including Christmas Island, Weipa, Darwin, Townsville, Perth and Wollongong. The committee carried out 23 inspections, which took in existing facilities and proposed construction sites as well as completed facilities. Twenty-one reports were tabled. The estimated cost of public works on which the committee reported during 1992 was $1.486 billion, which is a record.

PARA.TAB: Evidence collected on the references amounted to more than 5,000 pages of transcript, and 265 witnesses appeared before the committee at public hearings. By any measure, these outcomes are prodigious. As in past years, the committee's general report describes a number of what can be best described as difficult projects and raises a number of matters for concern which emerged during the year. The most difficult project was the inquiry into the public works aspects of the Civil Aviation Authority's proposed air traffic service centres at Brisbane and Melbourne.

On 3 June last year the chairman of the committee informed the House of Representatives about the difficulties and frustration which were experienced by the committee in the exercise of its duty by the unwillingness or inability of key CAA witnesses to answer relevant questions. Concerns were raised during the committee's inquiry into the selection of the successful tenderer for the provision of the hardware, software and buildings for the Australian advanced air traffic control system.

Accordingly, the committee recommended that the responsible minister set up an independent panel to carry out a thorough review of all aspects of the awarding of the contract. This, to the credit of the minister at the time—who was Senator Cook, I believe—and I might say the government as well, was done and a review was carried out by Mr Ian Macphee.

The key element of the committee's misgivings about the tender selection process concerned the process leading to the selection of the successful tenderer. The stand taken by the committee in recommending an independent review was vindicated.

The review found that the original tender selection process was departed from in a manner which was both unsound and unfair. The review also recommended that the two competing companies for the contract revert back to the original process. This has been done and next week the committee will resume its inquiry into the public works components of the TAAATS project.

I think, judging from media comments about the stand taken by the committee in relation to the matter, the committee has served the parliament and the people of Australia well. In fact the committee can take considerable pride in what Mr Macphee wrote about it in his report. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament has rights in the public interest and its all party Committees are one of the few practical checks upon the abuse of executive power.

The Public Works Committee is one of the hardest working, but normally low profile, Committees. Its current members are conscientious Parliamentarians without a desire for publicity or controversy. Nor do they have any undue sense of their own importance.
I quite agree with those remarks. I think Mr Macphee is obviously very sound in his observations. He concludes with a pithy observation. He states:
The behaviour of the Parliamentarians involved was in the best tradition of the public interest.

Another matter raised in this general report concerns the timing of references. The majority of references last year were received during the budget sittings. There has been an expectation by departments and agencies for the committee to undertake its inquiries and report within a short time span. Sometimes this is impossible. But in the future we do not want to see a repeat of 11 references being referred in the budget sittings, the majority of which have been referred late in the sittings, all needing to be reported on, on or before the summer recess.

PARA.TAB: So far this year the flow of references has been somewhat more even. I hope it continues that way. Sometimes during informal discussions with departmental officials the question of the mandatory limit was raised—the expectation being that the committee, in its wisdom, would agree to the limit being increased from $6 million to $10 million or perhaps $20 million.

The committee does not consider it appropriate for the limit to be increased. The estimated cost of the majority of projects examined during 1992 was well in excess of $6 million. The cost of only two references was marginally in excess of $6 million. These were for works of national importance which the committee felt deserved examination. Those projects related to the construction of a new permanent repository for the Australian Archives at East Burwood in Victoria, costing $6.5 million and a storage display facility for the Australian War Memorial in Mitchell in the Australian Capital Territory, costing about $6.5 million.

Since departments and agencies are now able to appoint their own design and construction authorities, without the involvement of the Australian Construction Services, there has been some discussion about compliance with building standards and local planning codes. Correspondence with the former minister for administrative services relating to the use of independent building certification services or agents is highlighted in this report.

Another matter of concern is the perennial question of inspections of overseas projects. For many years the committee has vigorously objected to the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act which, on one hand, require the committee to report on overseas works—embassies and high commissions—and, on the other, prevent it from travelling or meeting overseas to inspect properties and to take evidence.

One might say that perhaps that is inviting our committee to have junkets. But in my own experience, in my own time during the break, I went to Papua New Guinea to inspect a couple of projects that we had carried out there—one in excess of $40 million and another one which will cost some $20 million and will be referred to the committee this year. I do not believe that we as a committee can really understand the full problems that are being faced in PNG unless we visit the areas. Only by visiting there was I able to at least satisfy myself as to the large amount of money that was being spent, mainly on security matters. Unless one visits the country at first-hand, it is very hard to assess that particular aspect of the proposals.

Last year the committee examined two proposals involving overseas works, one in Thailand and the other in Fiji. The committee was unable to carry out on-site inspections. The benefits of site inspections and discussions with local staff would have far outweighed the associated costs in doing that. In fact, I think it would be much cheaper for the committee, or at least a subcommittee, to visit the sites than it would have been to bring the bureaucrats and the associated personnel here to Canberra to explain the situation.

During the year the committee continued to focus on the provision of more energy efficient building designs as well as the utilisation of alternative energy sources such as solar and wind power. On Christmas Island, the committee discovered that, although the island is within the belt of trade winds, the provision of wind driven electricity generating systems was not included in the proposed Christmas Island redevelopment. The committee recommended that a system be provided. A pilot study is under way and the committee is confident that it will be successful and will reduce the reliance on diesel generators on the island.

The committee also believes the success of this project will reduce, if not eliminate, significant latent conservatism amongst engineers and technicians towards embracing what in most comparable countries are already proven technologies. The committee has also been pursuing with some vigour the provision of solar hot water heaters in houses being constructed for the Defence Housing Authority. During the year the authority agreed that half the houses in a development at Seaward Village in Perth would be provided with solar hot water heaters.

From the point of view of occupational health and safety in air-conditioned buildings, legionnaire's disease is a spectre against which all proper precautions must be taken. The report mentions a number of aspects of legionnaire's disease and the exemplary steps being taken by the managers of Parliament House to ensure that all possible precautions are taken. These steps have wider ramifications and establish a baseline for all building managers. I urge all honourable senators to read that particular part of this report.

On the question of child-care, during the year the committee continued to focus attention on arrangements for the care of young children of staff to be employed in buildings under consideration. For example, the Australian Taxation Office, one of the largest public sector employers, advised the committee of a number of developments and initiatives in relation to the provision of child-care facilities in buildings upon which the committee has reported in recent years. Things are happening, and it is about time too.

Finally, I said at the beginning that 1992 was a busy year. The report mentions a number of references and associated inspections, and preparation of the report placed considerable strain not only on the committee but also on the staff. It was largely through the dedication, professionalism and hard work of the staff which enabled the committee to cope with such a heavy workload and to achieve, at times, difficult reporting targets. The committee is fortunate to have a dedicated staff led by the secretary, Peter Roberts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
