DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch I was speaking about the need to trace the history of this matter to put it in its proper context. I referred the Senate to the decision of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and to the committee's findings on that matter, which have received quite wide publicity.

PARA.TAB: There were two key findings to that report. The first, which has to be remembered, was that this was a decision for the High Court of Australia and that in the end the only way this matter would be resolved was by decision of the High Court. The second finding was that there was a real risk, which was significant, that that bill might be found to be unconstitutional. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) responded to the committee's concerns and, as requested by the committee, split the bills. It had been suggested that he might split the bills into five separate bills, but we are now dealing with eight bills. Two of those bills were referred to our committee again to examine and report back to the Senate.

The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) has become known as the test bill. This is the bill with which the government has sought to test the proposition advanced by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee that there are some doubts about the constitutionality of the approach adopted in the original bill. The bill addresses the major legal concern which worried the committee in its first report; that is, whether an increase in the rate of an existing tax is the imposition of taxation within the meaning of section 55 of the constitution.

By passing Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) we will test that issue and resolve the uncertainty around the parliament's powers in relation to taxation legislation. The government remains absolutely confident that that bill will survive that test and is in no doubt that the other seven bills are constitutionally valid. The committee heard evidence on both the bills that were the subject of its reference. The committee, finally, by majority—the government senators and Senator Spindler of the Democrats—resolved to recommend that Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) be passed.

The opposition has taken a rather curious position in relation to this matter. It was those opposite who raised the doubts about the constitutional validity of the approach adopted in the bill. It was they who sought and obtained legal advice. It was they who promoted the discussion regarding the uncertainty of the parliament's powers. It was they who sought to have the matter clarified. Now, when given the chance to have the matter tested, when given the opportunity to support the test bill, which was framed for the very purpose of responding to their concerns, they do not want to be in it. They seek to criticise the government for its response, which was the very response sought by the committee in responding to the concerns expressed over the first bill.

I think it is astounding that now that the government has moved to bring certainty to this area, to resolve any doubts and to provide the answers which we were all seeking, the opposition seeks to oppose it. I hope the Senate passes Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2) and allows for this question to be resolved in the only place it can be resolved—the High Court of Australia.

The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) clearly is not a test bill. It was drafted by the government to provide absolute certainty as to its constitutional validity. It seeks to implement a number of the measures contained in the budget, but it does not increase the rate of any existing tax. It is designed to remove the one major concern that existed about the validity of the original bill.

This bill does not contain the element which was the focus of most legal concern in the original Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993; nor does it seek to test those issues. It clearly is designed to avoid that issue and provide for constitutionally sound legislation. Despite that fact, there has been an attempt to call into question the legal credentials of that bill. In my view the argument is very weak. That is why there is a majority report, from the same committee that raised concerns about the original bill, that there is no problem with the constitutionality of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1).

Two concerns are raised in relation to this bill. The first is a wider view which, put simply, firstly, requires that the High Court overturn all of its precedents in taxation legislation and, secondly, requires the High Court to reject nearly all of Australia's tax legislation that has been framed since 1910. It is a quite preposterous proposition that does not gain much support at all. Even some of the critics of the original legislation are not prepared to back that sort of proposition.

The second concern raised about the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) is centred on the question of the credit union tax. Other senators have gone into detail about that issue. I do not want to delay the Senate by debating it in detail, but, essentially, that legislation seeks to remove the exemption from taxation that credit unions enjoy. It has been challenged as being somehow unconstitutional. The logic of the argument is that it is constitutional for the government to strike a rate of 33 per cent taxation on credit unions but it is not constitutional for the government to strike the rate at 20 per cent. It is a complete nonsense, it has no widespread support among the legal advice presented to the committee, and I think to try to use that as a basis for opposing the legislation is a very flimsy argument indeed.

Frankly, as I say, the arguments against this bill are very thin. They lack the substance of the arguments against the original Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. Evidence of the weakness, in my view, is that one of the lawyers giving evidence to the committee and also Senator Vanstone in her remarks today are unable to refute the argument based on legal precedent, case law and the history of taxation decisions by the High Court. They instead resort to an argument that basically states that the High Court could not possibly uphold its established line of reasoning in this case because it does not accord with commonsense or the understanding of the ordinary person in the street of normal practice.

Quite frankly, when lawyers turn to that sort of explanation to defend their position I get very worried. I have always been a bit cynical about lawyers. I always thought they made a good living out of the ordinary person in the street not being able to understand legislation and legal form. But I am astounded when lawyers, when confronted with evidence of precedents and case law, and strong arguments as to the constitutionality of this bill, resort to saying, `But it doesn't fit with the understanding that an ordinary person in the street would have and, therefore, the High Court will overturn all the precedents and all the case law and suddenly decide that it had been wrong in the past and find this bill to be unconstitutional'. I think that is highly far-fetched.

The question the Senate really has to ask is: what is the risk? There is always some risk that any legislation we pass might be successfully challenged on some ground before the High Court. But it is a question of saying whether that risk is significant and whether it is sufficient to really worry the Senate in exercising its proper role in reviewing the legislation. I think I gather support for that proposition by the remarks made by Senators Vanstone, O'Chee and Ellison in their additional remarks to the committee's original report. They made the following very sensible observation:

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously the government makes the political decision as to the format of its legislation. But the Parliament and the Australian people are entitled to be informed as to the risk the government takes in proceeding one way as opposed to another.

I think that is a reasonably fair statement of the position. Those senators on that occasion acknowledged the government's role and its entitlement to frame its own legislation. They also said that it was proper that the Senate make an assessment of the risk.

PARA.TAB: I think it is fair to say that the government senators on this committee have brought an impartial attitude to this whole debate. What we did in reorganising the first taxation deficit reduction bill was assess that risk, say that it was significant and depart from the government's reasoning, saying that on the basis of our concerns, the government ought to review its approach. The government, I might say, though not terribly happy with our view, nevertheless responded to that criticism and our concerns and did split the bills. That is what we are dealing with now.

I think that the government senators have established their credentials in terms of looking at these questions objectively. In our view, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) is constitutionally sound and the level of risk involved in the bill being passed by the Senate and then challenged is minimal.

No witness before the committee expressed the view that the level of risk was of the order that they had rated the risk involved in the original bill. Even the most ardent critics of the original bill were prepared to say that the level of risk that would result in our passing this bill was not of the same order. In fact, a number of the people who originally expressed some concerns about the original bill were not prepared to express those same concerns about the legislation now before the Senate.

In my view, there can be no case made for anything other than that there exists a very minimal risk that the legislation could be successfully challenged. Those risks are based on arguments that would require most of our taxation legislation to be invalidated by the High Court or, if one takes the narrower view, at least require the reading down or invalidation of other pieces of legislation passed by this parliament.

For those who want to raise the question of risks in this issue, one has to ask where those people were when we passed previous tax bills? Where were they when we passed other legislation that everyone admits included the same sort of devices and approach to the drafting of legislation? If they intend to oppose this, they have to oppose a range of other legislation that this parliament has passed with their acquiescence in the past. They are not doing that. It is convenient on this occasion to raise the legal issues because it provides some protection from dealing with the politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a ridiculous argument. See an error but don't correct it because you have not spotted it in the past.

—Senator Vanstone may say that, but she has not expressed a view as to what she will do about all the other legislation that will be read down by a successful challenge. Even the opposition members in their report on this matter are taking a much softer tone because I think they are far less confident, as they should be, of there being any real basis to the legal arguments that have been raised against this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I think the real issue is that they do not want to have to deal with the politics of the situation. They want to try to hide behind some sort of legalistic argument that gets them out of dealing with the political reality of where they stand on each of the measures in the government's budget. What we are suggesting is that they deal with the politics of the matter—deal with the legislation when it comes on. They should not try stunts that waste the time of the Senate by trying to hide behind some sort of legal mumbo jumbo that really is not supported by the evidence.

There is no basis for concern, other than a very minimal one, in relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1). That was conceded by nearly all the witnesses who appeared before the committee. Opposition members are drawing a long bow when they seek to raise the sorts of risks and concerns that they have advanced on this occasion.
Amendment negatived.

Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Carr:
That the following address-in-reply be agreed to:

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Denman, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to her.

—I take my place here today fully conscious of the responsibilities which now rest with me as a member of the Senate and honoured that I have the opportunity to serve Australia in this place as we work to accommodate the demands and changes to our society which will face us as we approach the 21st century. I am enthusiastic about the challenges which my new responsibilities will bring, and I look forward to representing the Australian Labor Party and the people of Tasmania over the next six years.

PARA.TAB: I owe a debt of gratitude to the many people who have supported me for this position: colleagues in the Labor Party; my family and friends; members of the community groups with whom I have worked; and the members of the trade union movement in Tasmania who have given me support, encouragement, advice and assistance. I thank them and trust I will justify their faith in me.

From a national perspective, I welcome the opportunity to continue to work on the implementation of the government's social justice agenda. I am proud of Labor's record of achievements in these areas and look forward to promoting those still to come in the years ahead. I am committed to continuing to work towards a more equitable society.

The words of Simone de Beauvoir that `humanity is something more than a mere species—it is an historical development' remind me very forcibly that I am part of a greater whole and that my contribution to date, and that which I will make in the future, owes as much to those who have gone before me and to those who will walk by my side over the next six years as it will to the particular skills and experience which I bring to this place.

I wish to acknowledge the work of colleagues, friends and Labor predecessors who have carried the flame of social justice and provided examples worth following. I am heartened that more women are taking their place in the political processes at all levels. There are some whom I would specifically wish to mention for their work and contribution to a better society.

I pay tribute to the work of Tasmanian state Labor parliamentarians Fran Bladel, Judy Jackson and Gill James who have worked tirelessly on issues such as community access and consultation, the prevention of domestic violence and the development of anti-discrimination measures; also former senator Susan Ryan and Senators Margaret Reynolds and Rosemary Crowley who have advanced these causes at a national level.

From my own community, women such as Mary Binks, convenor of the Tasmanian Women's Consultative Council, work within the Tasmanian community to provide the focus and direction leading to policy development and implementation processes at a political level. I pay tribute to Jean Hearn, the only other female Labor senator who has represented my state. There are many such men and women to whom I would wish to pay tribute, and I trust that they will know that their contribution is recognised and valued, not just by me, but by the many people whose lives they have affected.

There is one other whom I must mention today. I wish to begin my service to this chamber by paying tribute to the work and career of Michael Tate. The timing of Michael's resignation meant that his parliamentary colleagues did not have the opportunity to recognise his contribution in the usual manner. I am privileged to undertake this.

Michael Tate has given politics and Australia much more than 15 years of service as a senator, including his six years service as a minister. He has been a model for many by setting and maintaining high personal standards of integrity, loyalty and commitment. He has inspired us with his vision for a better, fairer society and he has worked tirelessly to earn the respect, trust and support of people for the ideals and values of the Australian Labor Party.

Michael has been a key player in achieving many of the party's social justice goals. Throughout his career, the principles of social justice have underpinned his work and values. In his first speech to the Senate on 23 August 1978, Michael referred to key areas which were of concern to him, vowing to tackle these issues during his parliamentary career. Among these issues was the need to revitalise a sense of national identity and to develop a set of national goals. He spoke out against the arms trade and the use of armed force as a serious and retrograde step. The diversion of resources on such a massive scale from the relief of human suffering, he pointed out, was fundamentally unjust. And he identified the social significance of trading and commercial life to equity, and the improvement of our quality of life.

When we look at Michael's aims and concerns in 1978 and compare them with his achievements in 1993, we can see further evidence of the remarkable commitment and constancy which characterised his career. He has achieved his goals to the considerable benefit of the Australian society. We now have stronger, fairer and more uniform laws nationally and across states, dealing with issues such as gun control, domestic violence, consumer protection, constitutional reform, police jurisdiction and police procedures. Justice and equity issues, values which the Australian Labor Party has always stood for, have been the cornerstone of Michael Tate's career and his achievements have honoured himself and the party.

His examples have provided strong inspiration for my own political and community involvement. I am proud to acknowledge the role that he has played in assisting me to develop my political skills. He has been a colleague, a mentor and a friend. Along with many of my fellow Tasmanians, I will miss him while he serves overseas. I regret that his political career has ended prematurely.

I joined the Australian Labor Party in 1982 because it was then, and still is, the most legitimate way to try to influence the decision making processes to improve the lives of people in our society. It is still the only political group with a proven track record in the areas of social justice. The contribution of people like Michael Tate shows us that no one person can solve the problems of inequalities which confront us.

As I take my place here today, I am conscious of the importance of clearly establishing my position within the context of the Labor philosophy and indicating those areas in which I believe I can make my contribution. Essentially, I stand for the promotion of social justice, cooperation and tolerance. I am a team player and believe that by working together we can achieve great things. The theme developed for the International Year of Youth in 1985, `Together we can be amazing', catches my sentiment. I believe in the dignity of humanity and in the right of each individual to be able to express his or her own particular sentiment. My aim over the next six years is to promote social justice issues related to access and equity which will enhance the dignity and the rights of all in our society.

With particular focus on the areas of health, education and justice, through an increasing involvement in processes of decision making and community consultation, equity and access to information services provided by government agencies are priority issues which I wish to promote and develop. My own experiences as a woman, teacher, parent, and as the manager of a community legal centre and of many community groups has increased my commitment to equity issues and heightened my awareness that, no matter how great the gains have been over the past 10 years, we still have much to do.

There are two issues arising from these areas which I believe will increase in importance over the next years: firstly, access to justice through our legal system; and, secondly, the construction of a process which will allow full community debate on medical ethics. Consistent, clear prioritising in the decision making processes which drive the allocation of the health dollars at state and federal levels need to be established. These issues are linked by questions related to public funding, equity and justice.

Access to justice through our legal system is a critical issue which must be addressed as a matter of urgency. Labor governments have done much to make the law more accessible to Australians over the last 10 years. We now have effective networks of community legal centres and the provision of legal aid to people in need. This has done much to demystify the law and enable everyone who faces the courts to be represented professionally and equitably. However, areas remain where improvements need to be made. These areas relate to equity and access in justice through the legal system outside the courts.

We have now reached the stage where the complexity of our society means that we are faced with an increasing number of situations where speedy access to legal advice prior to reaching the courts is not only desirable but also necessary if we are serious about the provision of justice for all. It should not be only the privileged who are able to access the types of advice which can often circumvent the trauma of legal proceedings.

With regard to the second of these issues, the promotion of informed community debate on questions related to medical ethics and the allocation of public funding for health care are long overdue. Where debate has occurred, it has tended to be reactive to the moral and ethical repercussions of medical technology not properly being considered before the technology has been introduced into our health care system.

All too often, costs tend to be the catalysts which drive the ethics. While these issues are separate, they are obviously linked. Modern technology has meant that more and more costly and complex procedures are being developed, and the traditional boundaries and moralities are being challenged. While these developments have undoubtedly improved the lives of many, they have also presented ethical and funding problems for health administrators. Questions related to quality of life, equity and opportunity to gain access to the new technology and moral and legal issues related to procedures such as the IVF programs have all presented enormous challenges to our society.

Communities have expected that they will have access to high quality medical care, and generally in Australia we have been fortunate in providing this to the vast majority of the population. However, as medical science becomes more complex and more costly, we need to recognise that we simply do not have the capacity to provide unlimited resources without question or community accountability. We must be clear about our community priorities and more specific about what we expect our health care dollar to deliver.

We must also acknowledge the responsibility we face as a society for the moral and ethical repercussions of the technologies which we sanction through the allocation of public funding. The establishment of these priorities, responsibilities and shared goals can be resolved only through greater community participation in the decision making processes.

New South Wales began the process of raising the medical ethics issue several years ago when the New South Wales Department of Health commissioned a report by Dr Niki Ellis to undertake a study of the relative costs of modern health care procedures. Taking $75,000 as the baseline, Dr Ellis's report compared the relative costs of neonatal intensive care to open heart surgery, hip replacement surgery and quit smoking courses. Her work has provided the basis for the examination of ethical and funding issues in public health in this country.

Although ethicists and medical administrators are concerned about the issue of how we as a community make decisions about the appropriate way to spend our health care dollar, the issue urgently needs to be addressed by the broader community. It is now time to construct a framework for community consultation and debate on this most important issue. It is an issue which should include and involve all members of the community. The health care professionals, administrators, community groups and all members of society have a role to play in identifying priorities and clarifying community expectations of our health care system. Greater democracy in decision making on health issues may do much to resolve the dilemma which experts face.

I believe that we as politicians have an important role to play in reaffirming the right of the Australian people to be active in shaping the type of health care system we have in the future. I intend to play a role in facilitating and promoting this most important debate over the next six years. I hope to assist in the development of decision making processes on health issues which are inclusive of all facets of health care service delivery and which acknowledge the importance of developing a holistic approach to the establishment of community health care priorities. This will mean reaffirming our commitment to the less glamorous, but nonetheless critically important, aspects of health care service delivery, such as formally acknowledging the role of home based carers. This recognition is a justice and moral issue every bit as much as it is a health issue.

Next week is National Carers Week. It is timely, therefore, to consider the enormous changes which have taken place in our society this century and to assess the impact which these changes will have on a growing group of individuals whose work and contribution to our society is often overlooked, not just by governments but by a whole range of service providers, community groups and even family members. Home based carers provide care, love and companionship in a selfless and often unrecognised manner. More importantly perhaps, they enable many people to live full lives in dignity and peace, often at a great personal cost.

Most of the responsibility for the care of children, the elderly, the sick and the disabled falls to women in our society. For too long governments and society have traded on the nurturing role of women as a justification to absolve themselves of much of their responsibility to provide appropriate care for carers.

Issues such as access to information, support services, respite care and properly indexed equitable pension scales must be better coordinated and integrated into existing community health care programs more fully. I intend to build on the work already begun nationally by previous Labor governments to redress the imbalance which has existed for far too long. I refer particularly to the work of Brian Howe and Peter Staples, and presently by Senator Graham Richardson, to increase funding for HACC services, respite services and community living programs and to develop a clear policy statement.

In Tasmania, the work done by Fran Bladel and the women on the Tasmanian Women's Consultative Council to investigate the needs of home based carers and to provide recognition for the importance of their role in our community has established a framework for government action at a state level. I believe that I can play an important role in encouraging other states to follow Tasmania's lead and identify the particular concerns and needs of home based carers so that we can work towards the development of a coherent and consistent national strategy to support their work.

The Russian poet Yevtushenko once said that justice is like a train that is nearly always late. He was right. Like him, I believe that justice, if it is running late or lagging behind some current development, will eventually arrive but that often we have to struggle, to wait, to wonder and to hope that it will not arrive too late to prevent damage or disorder in some other part of our lives. In my own state we are still waiting for this train to deliver the anti-discrimination legislation. Nationally, there is still work to be done to make sure that everyone has fair access to justice and to the benefits which modern technology can provide. I aim to do something to improve the train's timetable of justice over the next six years—to make sure that the train arrives on time as often as possible—so that those people most in need of assistance are given all the opportunities they require to access the means by which justice is delivered in our society.

Finally, I wish to thank my family and friends who have travelled from Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales and my fellow colleagues. I also thank my staff, Meryl, Gloria and Bryan, for their help and support.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

The purpose of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) is to repeal the Tax Legislation Amendment Act 1992, which was the government's so-called l-a-w, law, bill, which comprised the income tax cuts announced at the time of the One Nation statement. The bill supersedes that act by bringing forward by 7 1/2 months the first stage of the government's One Nation tax cuts whilst, at the same time, deferring into never-never land—in effect, totally abandoning—the much larger second stage tax cuts that had been proposed at that time. The bill also introduces a small tax rebate for low income earners.

PARA.TAB: One of the extraordinary features of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) is that it contains a provision which formally links the commencement of the first stage—now the only stage—of the tax cuts to the passage of all the government's bills to increase sales tax across the board, to impose a huge 55 per cent increase in the tax on wine, to increase taxes on credit unions, to change the tax required for friendly societies and to extend fringe benefits tax in such a way as to put at risk up to 20,000 jobs in the tourism industry. There are other bills which are not linked in this way, but which also impose other savage increases, particularly increases in the tax and excise on fuel and tobacco.

With respect to this bill, the government is proposing to make its greatly reduced tax cuts apply 7 1/2 months earlier than legislated last year and to introduce a measly tax rebate of $2.88 a week for low income earners as partial and totally inadequate compensation for the savage indirect tax hikes across the board to which it is subjecting them. Low income earners will not even receive this miserable, minuscule rebate until close to Christmas next year, whereas all the tax increases apply before Christmas this year—and many of them applied from budget night, 17 August 1993. In the budget this year, the government initially proposed an even more insulting rebate of only $1.92 per week. This budget hits the poor and the low income earners, and it hits them very hard. So much for this government's notions of social justice, compassion and concern for the needy in our community!

On behalf of the coalition, I have moved amendments to the bill which break this link between the government's income tax proposals contained in the bill before us and the sales tax bills which are increasing the main raft of indirect taxes. The coalition is simply not prepared to see the poor in our community, the low income earners, particularly single income families with young children, suffer at the hands of an incompetent and uncaring government in the way that is envisaged through the linkage provisions in this bill. There is no earthly, logical or technical connection between the income tax proposals in this bill and the savage indirect tax increases in the bills which are the subject of the linkage clauses.

The government now claims that the linkage is relevant and necessary because the indirect tax increases are necessary to fund its income tax proposals. That is not what the government said before and during the March election campaign this year and in the many months preceding it in 1992. Indeed, it said consistently quite the opposite in September last year, at the time of the introduction of the bills to give a two-stage personal income tax cut—and I remind the committee that the two stages were to occur on 1 July 1994 and 1 January 1996, but without anything at all by way of income tax relief for anyone earning less than $20,700 a year at that time. When the One Nation tax cuts bill was introduced on 15 September last year, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we can pay for our personal tax cuts.
The very following day, on 16 September, in the House of Representatives, the Treasurer said:
I emphasise that this—
that is, the income tax cuts—
will be achieved without resort to any new taxes.

In his now infamous interview with Kerry O'Brien on the ABC's Lateline program on 19 November last year, just three months or so before the election, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) reiterated that assertion even more strongly. He said:
What I'm promising is not to put up tax.
In his 1993 election policy speech in February this year, the Prime Minister told the nation and those unsuspecting voters who did not know him like we do that, with Labor:
. . . there will be no big, new taxes.

Virtually the day after the election, the government started to welsh on these quite unequivocal commitments. It knew that it had promised the world and it always knew that it would never be able to deliver it. That is what the linkage clauses in this bill are all about. They are a direct consequence of the government's broken promises on tax. It said that taxes would not go up. Of course they were going to go up under this big spending, incompetent, discredited government and—I would have to say, in the events of recent days and weeks—this totally discredited Prime Minister and Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: The coalition believes that the government should deliver the tax cuts that it promised the people before and during the election, including the income tax cuts, with no strings attached and no tying of the cuts to increases in other taxes for which the government has no mandate whatsoever. We will support the income tax reduction proposals in this bill provided there are no strings attached. Why should the income tax cuts of the hard-pressed, indeed, oppressed, taxpayers of Australia—especially the low and medium income earners—some of which are not due until some 12 months hence, be dependent on savage tax increases on most of the day-to-day items that people purchase?

The linkage clauses are unfair and harsh. They deliberately and comprehensively smash the government's solemn pre-election promises. They represent a blatant attempt to blackmail the Senate into voting for an increase in sales tax across the board, a savage increase—a more than 50 per cent hike—in the tax on wine, an increase in taxes on credit unions and an increase in fringe benefits tax at a potential cost, as I said earlier, of 20,000 jobs to the tourism industry.

Although the coalition will support the government's personal tax cuts and rebate proposals contained in this bill—provided, as I say, that the linkage clauses are removed—I point out again to the chamber that the bill represents a major retreat from the income tax cuts that the Prime Minister so arrogantly thrust down our throats recently as being l-a-w, law, that is, already legislated. This bill today repeals that legislation enacted last year—that l-a-w, law. This bill sends into never-never land two-thirds of the tax cuts promised by the government in its One Nation statement of February 1992 and put into l-a-w, law, during the budget session in 1992 as a partial and totally inadequate offset to abandoning the tax cut due on 1 January 1996.

I remind the Senate that that tax cut comprised about two-thirds of the $8.5 billion promised cut. As a sop to this abandonment of more than $5 billion worth of tax cuts, the government is bringing forward by 7 1/2 months to 15 November 1993—provided we are good and let all its other bills go through—the first tranche of its 1992 legislation, which was due to apply from 1 July 1994.

As I intimated earlier, it has bowed to pressure, but only as a result of justifiable outrage from the coalition and a wide range of concerned agencies and individuals. Income earners below $20,700 were getting no relief from the l-a-w cuts of 1992. The government has now very grudgingly given them a token rebate of $2.88 per week. As I said, it started off by offering the measly and insulting sum of $1.92 per week. But again, that is only to be received after the end of this financial year because it is in the form of a rebate.

I have formally moved the three amendments circulated in my name on behalf of the coalition. The amendments are interrelated and simply remove the offensive linkage clauses in the bill. I hope that they will receive the Senate's support. If they do, they will ensure that taxpayers receive a tax cut on 15 November 1993, regardless of what happens to the government's other plans to increase a wide range of unfair and regressive taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the coalition's amendments which remove the linkage, but not quite for the same reasons or all the reasons that were put by Senator Short. The Australian Democrats have always been of the view that in the current state of our economy the tax cuts are unaffordable and that the funds are needed for capital investment in order to generate jobs.

PARA.TAB: When this budget was brought in, we offered to support any move by the government to cut out, in particular, high income earners from the benefits of those tax cuts. We believe that this is a determined effort by the government to gain votes from middle or middle-high income Australia and feel that this attempt should not be supported.

However, we accept that the government is in charge of the structural features of this budget and that it would be irresponsible for us to attack the budget's basic financial structure. This version that we are now debating in trying to link bill No. 3, which contains the tax rebate and the income tax reductions, with all the other provisions is the third bit of evidence before the Senate that the government is trying to intimidate the Senate into doing its bidding. PARA.TAB: Therefore, it should have been rejected out of hand and the government forced to come back with a piece of legislation which did not include the linkage clause. I also indicate that I believe that the provisions in the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No.3 ) relating to taxation are inequitable. They fail to address a very key principle—that is, horizontal tax equity. That is something that has not been considered in the debate either publicly or within this chamber. It is something that needs to be addressed.

It is probably too late to address this issue on this occasion, but it seems to me to be totally inequitable for government taxation measures to ignore the fact that a particular income is shared amongst a number of dependants. This measure continues to ignore that fact. It is inequitable that the taxation system imposes taxation on an income irrespective of the number of persons dependent upon that income.

I mentioned this because the government said that this will be a boon to middle Australia. There are certain people in middle Australia who will not consider it to be a very big boon at all because they are the ones who are shouldering the burdens—the people whom the government and the taxation department refuses to acknowledge are playing their part in supporting, nurturing and developing the future taxpayers of this country. Whilst that situation continues to exist, we are going to have a wide number of people disappointed and disillusioned by that fact.

Surely it is an injustice if the number of persons dependent upon an income is not recognised for the purpose of taxation. It is recognised for a whole range of other purposes, but not for this purpose. I have digressed somewhat from the principle of linkage which we are discussing. I hope that this was a smart alec doing a try on and not really government policy. I expect better from governments at this particular point. I hope that when this linkage issue is unlinked by the Senate, the government will recognise that and accept it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —As many honourable senators who are in the chamber would know, it is not usually my style, when debating tax matters, to make lengthy contributions when the arithmetic is pretty plain. This is an issue that is of sufficient importance, and I probably need to outline the governments position in relation to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) in general and the linkage matter in particular. Even though I can count, it probably also means that we will have to have a division on this matter. It is a matter of significance to the government and it would be inappropriate to allow it to go unchallenged. For the record, I give that as a prior indication.

PARA.TAB: I think many people would know that it is not my usual style and I am not about to adopt it as a norm, but this is an exceptional circumstance. I mainly want to talk about linkage. Other senators said a number of other things in the course of this debate to which I will respond.

The first thing that seems to be substantially understated, although not unacknowledged by some, is the extent and significance of the bring forward of the tax cuts that this bill includes. It is very important for a large number of Australians and Australian families.

I will come to Senator Harradine's more general point about horizontal tax equity in a moment because it is an important point. Even those families benefit. It may be that if the government were to go in the direction that Senator Harradine wished those families would benefit even more. There is no doubt that there is benefit to middle income families and people all around Australia who are dependent upon wages and salaries. They will overwhelmingly benefit.

The first thing to remember is that a very significant impact of this bill, if it is passed and if the arrangements are such that it can come into force, is that there will be a substantial bring forward that will benefit many Australian families in the lead up to Christmas. It will be part of the economic stimulus in the budget that will help economic growth and the creation of jobs. Those two things are important and are underestimated, so they need to be reiterated.

There have also been some derisory remarks made about the $150 rebate for low income earners. Those who think that this is a matter of no or small consequence have obviously never lived on a low income. It seems to me to be quite clear that for an overwhelming number of low income families this will be a very important element in their family finances when it comes into effect—as I am confident it will.

We have to remember that we are talking about people with a very low tax bill. Many of the low income earners affected will have their total tax bill wiped out by the $150 rebate. To say that somehow or other the government would be wonderfully magnanimous if it increased the rebate even further, fails to take into account that the $150 eliminates the whole income tax burden of many of the people to whom we are referring.

It will be a substantial benefit to many Australian families. The rebate and the bring forward are important. We have had a debate at the second reading stage about this matter and I do not want to divert us, but I want to make a point about it.

The other thing I want to say briefly about the budget and low income families is that the response of people who seek to focus on the distributive equity—I am not going to Senator Harradine's horizontal tax equity point, which is quite separate and about which I will make a comment in a minute—ignores entirely the outlays side of the budget. Free dental services will be provided to card holders by 1 July next year. There will be a substantial benefit to those in greatest need funded out of the revenue measures in the budget. So those opposite just cannot take a one sided assessment of equity. The greatest equity role of government lies in what it does on the outlays side of the budget.

A number of things have been said about the relationship between these measures and the government's original announcement. I have not got the announcement in front of me at the moment. My recollection is that on 16 September last year Treasurer Dawkins, in speaking about these tax measures, made two important points that tend not to be commented on because they do not suit some of the participants in this debate. Apart from the commitment that we would not introduce a GST, the Treasurer announced that the government would not increase the overall burden of tax and it would take measures to broaden the tax base. Those were the commitments that were made on 16 September. They tend to be overlooked because people do not like them. That is part of the overall review of the tax system that is under way.

Before I turn briefly to the linkage clauses, I want to briefly comment on Senator Harradine's horizontal tax equity point. He has made it on a number of occasions. Of course, he is quite right that we cannot amend this bill to accommodate that point because it is much too complex. That does not dismiss from consideration that proposal.

It is not for me to stand up here and announce some new government policy and I do not intend to do so. As Senator Harradine knows, it is a question of significant interest to a number of people in the government and it is a proposal that is considered worthy of serious consideration. I am not in a position to go further until the government makes a decision, and I will not be running around here unilaterally announcing new government policies.

It is not an easy issue; a lot of complexities are involved. I am not saying that to put Senator Harradine down because I know that he is aware of those complexities. We cannot, therefore, just wander into such a change, but it does warrant and is receiving consideration. It is not a matter, as I know he is aware, that we can address and resolve in this bill, although it is a perfectly appropriate issue for him to raise in the discussion around the bill.

I turn now to the linkage clauses, which are the key element of the amendments before us. The Senate has to realise—and, I am sure, overwhelmingly does realise—that, with the arithmetic of this house, it may well be that it can delete from this bill the linkage to the passage of other bills and say that, as a consequence, this measure should apply from whatever date it specifies. Putting aside questions of royal assent, the parliament constitutes two houses—the House of Representatives and the Senate. The House of Representatives does not share the Senate's view so it is highly unlikely that an agreed bill will pass without a linkage clause. That is the first thing to say.

The second thing to say is that, even if the Senate takes this clause out, nothing in the rhetoric, nothing in the vote, can change the reality of the fundamental macro-economic linkage that exists. By carrying a resolution here, we cannot change reality. The reality is that what some in the Senate—not everybody—are seeking to do is have all the revenue reduction measures without the compensating revenue increase measures. We cannot do that; we cannot change reality by a resolution of the Senate. It does not matter what the Senate resolves, the macro-economic linkage will exist and a responsible government will need to take those linkages into account, and we will. I simply make that very clear.

I understand the sensitivities that people have raised about their pride as senators. The Senate has a lot of power but it cannot change reality by resolution. It is not a question of blackmailing the Senate—I understand the rhetorical flourish, it is the sort of word we all use from time to time when we want to add a bit of emphasis to an argument we are putting—it is simply making the reality evident. It is making it clear what the government considers is the necessary macro-economic responsibility that it as the government has to exercise. The Senate does not have to exercise that responsibility because it is not its role, but at some stage the Senate does have to recognise that it is the responsibility of the government to manage the economy. We do have to be in a position where we can deliver unpalatable measures as well as palatable ones; unpopular things as well as popular ones.

Quotes by Fraser, Menzies and others have been thrown around in broad terms about whether we should or should not do particular things now. We got into some wonderful historic speculation about who might have said what and to whom over the last quarter of a century. What those people have said is that it is necessary to recognise the benefit that the Westminster system has brought to Australia against the presidential system in the United States. It is the capacity of the executive government to deliver on packages of measures that include tough and unpopular measures that presidents and the executive government of the United States have not been able to deliver on so successfully. Perhaps there is a sign that President Clinton is being a little more successful, but over the last 10 or 20 years the United States government has not been able to deliver, at profound macro-economic cost to the United States. That is not a course to which we will lightly accede, whatever view the Senate might wish to express about this bill.

I reiterate that I acknowledge from the speeches made by the four honourable senators that the overwhelming majority of Senate opinion is contrary to the government's view. But we stick by what we think is right and responsible, even though we accept that in the short term it may not be popular. Therefore, we will vote against the amendments and we will pursue our position as far as it is possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, these amendments are suggestions for a top-up tax. They make a very slight change to the schedules in clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3). They propose to change the top schedule to cover incomes between $50,000 and $100,000. The tax rate remains the same at 47 per cent. They also propose that incomes exceeding $100,000 attract a 52 per cent tax rate.

PARA.TAB: The federal government has neglected to tell the Australian public of the hole of up to $3 billion in its deficit reduction strategy. As we announced last month, the budget estimates make no provision for any legal costs or compensation involved in new programs arising from the legislative response to the High Court's decision on native title. These are likely to be well over $1 billion over the next few years.

The budget outlays have no costings for labour market assistance beyond the run-out of the existing programs. The shortfall between the forecast figure and the likely real cost is $2 billion. We are very concerned that the government continues to deplete the direct taxation revenue base and attempts to substitute indirect taxes which are insufficient to meet the known expenditure requirements over the next four years.

The introduction of a top-up tax, or new top marginal tax rate, would provide valuable revenue and make the tax system more progressive. The government estimates that such a tax would raise $850 million over the next four years. It would affect less than one per cent of taxpayers. Because it would be implemented in conjunction with existing reductions in marginal tax rates, it would involve someone on $120,000 per annum paying a mere $86 more each year. This is equivalent to an extra $1.64 per week—not an unbearable burden for someone on more than $2,300 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support these amendments. We believe that they take the income tax argument back where it should be; that is, taking into account the capacity to pay. I believe the government has neglected that aspect. This argument has been on the table for a long time.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take the Senate back to 17 October 1990 when I moved an amendment to increase the marginal tax rate for incomes above $100,000 to 60 per cent. That increase would have yielded $600 million in that year. No doubt the figures would need to be adjusted now. I believe that the government has lost sight of the principle. We are being fed the argument that the incentive to work of people at a certain income level will be diminished simply because they have to pay a higher tax rate. I believe that that is a lot of nonsense. I believe that people at that level work because they enjoy the work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Panizza considers this laughable. He made the same sorts of responses when I moved a similar amendment in 1990. I do not expect that either the coalition or the government will be supporting these amendments, because they both look after people in the high income brackets and believe that benefits to those who are at the bottom of the pile will trickle down. I would have thought that the figures, which very clearly show that there is a growing disparity between rich and poor in Australia, would prove that that theory simply does not work.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is time that we took a hard look at what we are doing in our taxation policy. We are now at about the third lowest level of the OECD countries in terms of raising tax revenue for public expenditure on health, job generation, education and other areas where clearly the need is high.

Clearly, we need to raise our expenditure and develop a cohesive nation instead of going further down the road to becoming two nations—those that are in jobs and are the haves and can command a high income, and those that increasingly are without work because we are not spending on public investment expenditure which could generate jobs and because we open our borders to cheap imports which put more and more people out of work and which cause factories to close. I believe it is time we got back to this argument. I congratulate Senator Margetts for bringing forward these amendments and the Democrats will certainly support them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take much time of the Senate. Both Senator Margetts and Senator Spindler have been brief; I will return the compliment. These amendments take a significant step further the proposition that in some way or other it is the Senate that should decide what the tax regime of the country is. Instead of merely seeking to oppose some government proposals, we now have a proposal for the Senate to actually write in new tax scales. That is another step further.
—You can't do that constitutionally; you just can't do that.

—As Senator Watson has just interjected, if one takes the opposition's interpretation of the constitution that was put forward in the debate this morning, one certainly would have to consider that it is beyond the power of the Senate to do this. It is an arguable point, but certainly many people would have the view that the Senate cannot do this by amendment. Certainly the view consistent with that position that was put earlier by some senators would mean that this could at least only be done by request.

PARA.TAB: I think there is a more important principle about just picking and choosing and saying, `We will pick this rate out and put it up' without it being part of an overall tax strategy. I accept the right of the Greens and the Democrats to make debating points about their disagreement with the overall government tax strategy and to use this as a vehicle to do that and to say, `We don't agree with the approach to income tax that the government is putting forward', but as a way of going about setting tax policy and tax rates it is not sustainable.

These amendments have some other shortcomings. One is the great difficulty we get when proposals like this are considered in isolation. Let me put a hypothetical situation to the Senate. I use this example only because I saw some months ago some newspaper speculation about it so it should not start any new scares, because I am only being hypothetical. Assume the government, to fund its employment measures, did want to put some sort of levy on income tax. This would be a distinct barrier to our doing so because we would have already put this levy on but not for that purpose. So it would suddenly build a hurdle to doing something which I think, with sober consideration, the Greens and the Democrats would support.

So I think there are some policy shortcomings in the proposal. There are some drafting shortcomings. I do not think these amendments would achieve the purposes that are set down for them in drafting terms. I am not going to make too much of that because I do not see that there is any prospect that the amendments will be carried so there is no point getting into nitpicking detail about drafting, but I do think there are some problems with that.I have said that there are some constitutional problems.

The two problems with proceeding casually down this route are that, firstly, you open the door to people who have that capacity incorporating—transferring their income from the PAYE tax system to the company tax system. I do not want to make too much of that. A lot of people make that a very major point. I think these days anti-tax avoidance measures are sufficiently strong to limit that, but it cannot eliminate it altogether and it is an issue. Some people would say it is a very major issue in this problem and they raised it when we proposed to reduce the company tax rate. I do not regard it as being as serious as some others do, but it exists and cannot be brushed aside entirely.

The second and related question is that measures such as this actually do not catch the richest people in Australia, they catch upper income PAYE taxpayers. Those who are in the PAYE system as employees, particularly public servants—the upper income people—do not pay their tax in that way and one tends to find that we are being very discriminatory in terms of who gets hit. I do not want to say that there is never a circumstance, because one could argue all of those points as to why the rate should be 45c instead of 47c or whatever.

I accept that it is a legitimate debate to put forward in the Senate the view that the income tax rate on upper income earners should be higher. That is part of the debate Senator Spindler and I have had for three years, because I think we had this same debate on the occasion he moved that amendment. Others in this chamber have had it and will continue to have it. There will be further changes in tax rates and we will have these sorts of debates again, with the opposition saying they are too high or the Democrats saying they are too low or all of those.

The government is not going to accept these amendments at this time. We are strongly opposed to this as a mechanism for setting, somewhat at random, tax rates separate from an overall strategy. Apart from the constitutional and technical problems with the bill, I think there is a profound policy problem, and we do not support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the minister's arguments and I shall not prolong the debate by debating the technical aspects and the pros and cons of using this particular mechanism, but I think it would be appropriate, seeing as the minister said the government would not accept this measure at this stage but that the debate would continue, to ask whether the minister is prepared to accept as a basis for the ongoing debate that capacity to pay should be a criterion in setting tax rates?
—It is.
—It is vertical and horizontal.

—Capacity to pay often not only depends on the income, but also on the number of persons dependent upon that income. I think the Senate should be grateful to Senator Margetts for bringing this forward and for the points that have been made around the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I wish to indicate one of the reasons why I am not supporting these particular amendments—they do not address the dual income family whose combined income exceeds $100,000. There are very many of those in this city of Canberra, particularly without children. As honourable senators will have seen, those in the highest pecking order now in Australia in economic terms are what are known as DINKS. I do not know where that acronym came from, but it stands for `dual income, no kids'.

This particular proposition could well mean that such a couple could have an income of, say, $110,000 where one person has an income of $70,000—I am not sure what that is in Public Service terms—and the other an income of $40,000, making a total of $110,000. The latter would be taxed at a rate of 43c in the dollar and the former at a rate of 47c in the dollar, whereas a person who has an income of $110,000—a one-income family with eight kids—would be taxed at the rate proposed in this amendment, 52 per cent.

Clearly that is inequitable. It does not address the horizontal tax equity question. As has been perfectly stated by Senator Spindler in his question to Senator McMullan and in Senator McMullan's response, capacity of the pay is an important aspect. But that also involves, as Senator Watson interjected, both vertical and horizontal equity. That is the reason that I am not supporting this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has admitted—and I am pleased to say it—that there is a hole in the budget and that it needs to fill it—if not now, in the near future. Perhaps we have stolen the government's thunder in that it might be looking at a similar measure. The Greens do not mind which particular measures the government chooses, but it is a bit rich for the government to suggest that it is irresponsible for the Greens or other parties—the Australian Democrats or the opposition—to try to ameliorate some of the poorer considered aspects of the budget because at this stage it will not look at any alternative sources of revenue.

PARA.TAB: All we have done in this proposal is to make a suggestion. The minister also suggested that the problem is that there is too much of a temptation to transfer funds into company tax. Of course, if company tax is 33 per cent, obviously that is a temptation. The problem is not in this kind of proposal. The problem is in the unrealistically low level of company tax that the government has perhaps irresponsibly promised that the community will pay or subsidise.

I appreciate the stated support of the Democrats. If this is not the kind of amendment that the Government would support at this stage, I ask ministers please to think of another one that is more equitable than many of the revenue collection measures in the current budget.
