A couple of months later, on 19 November, the Prime Minister, (Mr Keating) said, in an interview on the ABC's television program Lateline with Kerry O'Brien, `What I am promising is not to put up tax'. In the election campaign policy speech of February this year the Prime Minister told the nation, amongst other things, `And with Labor there will be no new big tax increases'. He said that that was a repeat of what he had told the parliament last year in September when he said, `We can pay for our personal tax cuts'.

Therefore, these bills fly absolutely and totally in the face of the unequivocal promises and commitments that this government made over a lengthy period to deceive the Australian public before and during the 1993 election campaign. They are a deceitful and a very damaging budget measure. They represent a betrayal of the Labor Party's election promises and commitments. The government has no mandate for them. They are, quite simply, bad law.

Many of my colleagues wish to speak in this debate on these bills, so I will not detain the Senate too much longer. But I want to read a couple of points into the record in view of the quite scurrilous attacks that have been made by this government, particularly by the Prime Minister, his Treasurer and ministers in this house—notably and, in particular, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans—about the opposition's handling of the budget bills this year. It makes for very interesting reading to look at what Labor luminaries have said in the past about the question of whether the Senate has the right—moral, constitutional or whatever—to amend, change or oppose government legislation, particularly in the form of tax bills and sales tax bills.
In his budget response on 25 August 1970, the then Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, Gough Whitlam, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it clear at the outset that our opposition to this Budget is no mere formality. We intend to press our opposition by all available means and all related measures in both Houses. If the motion is defeated we will vote against the bills here and in the Senate. Our purpose is to destroy this Budget and to destroy the Government which has sponsored it.

When questioned today in the Senate about Mr Whitlam's statement, Senator Gareth Evans said, `Oh, it was a quixotic statement by a leader 20 years ago'. What absolute nonsense. It was a very definite and accurate statement of Labor Party policy towards this matter. In 1970 one of the leading Labor figures of all time in this Senate—Senator Lionel Murphy—said in relation to a similar matter:

There are no limitations on the Senate in the use of its constitutional powers, except the limitations imposed by discretion and reason. The Australian Labor Party has acted consistently in accordance with the tradition that we will oppose in the Senate any tax or money Bill, or any other financial measure, whenever necessary, to carry out our principles and policies.

Just last week, one of Labor's former very distinguished senators—whom many of us here would know—ex-Senator John Wheeldon, had something to say about the Prime Minister's pathetic attempt to rewrite history in this area of the role of the Senate in relation to tax bills. John Wheeldon wrote in the Sydney Daily Telegraph Mirror last Friday:

Conflict over the Senate's treatment of a Budget is nothing new. While I was a Labor Senator we repeatedly voted against Coalition Budgets, and I well remember Lionel Murphy, when he was Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, announcing that we would defeat the Coalition's Budget and bring the then government down.
John Wheeldon went on to say in that article last Friday:
To claim that there is a convention or a tradition that the Senate is obliged to pass the Budget with or without amendment is completely without historical or legal foundation.

Those statements echo very closely what the present Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, said when he was in opposition in 1981 and when the then Labor opposition attacked and opposed very savagely and very vigorously the Fraser government's sales tax proposals in that budget. Senator Gareth Evans said a whole raft of things. In a notable second reading debate speech on those bills, he said that there were six points he wanted to make in explaining the then Labor opposition's strong reasons for rejecting the 1981 budget sales tax bills. He said:

Firstly, there is a clear distinction in principle between Bills on which the survival of a government depends and those on which it does not. In the former category are crucial money bills, such as the Supply Bills . . . and the Appropriation Bills. In the latter category are not only all non-money bills but also lesser money bills, such as those imposing particular fees or taxes . . .
He went on to elaborate on that point. Further, he said:
The sixth point I want to make is that there can be no question of a mandate of any kind for these particular sales tax bills.

That was because he claimed that the Fraser government had not given prior indication to the electorate about those bills. If ever a government has failed prior to an election to give any advance notice about its post-election proposals to increase indirect taxes savagely, it is this Keating-Dawkins government. As I said before, everything it said before the election was in contradistinction to the proposition that it would be putting up sales taxes and indirect taxes as a whole. That includes the savage, massive and very destructive fuel tax increases that are proposed in other bills that we will be debating soon.

PARA.TAB: I wish to read into the Hansard a final point made by Senator Gareth Evans in 1981. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make, although it is by no means the least important, is that there is a whole series of precedents in regard to revenue measures in recent Budgets which the Australian Labor Party has voted against in both Houses, without anyone raising cries of inconsistency, hypocrisy or constitutional impropriety.

So much for the hypocrisy and cant that is going on at the moment from the government about the opposition's handling of these tax bills. We have a responsibility on behalf of the electorate to examine these bills. If we disagree with them, if we believe that the government has no mandate for them and if we regard them as harsh, regressive and unfair, we would be failing our responsibility to the Australian people to do anything other than what we are doing—that is, to vigorously oppose these bills.

PARA.TAB: It is simply incorrect—it is a lie—for the government to say that defeat of the sales tax bills will somehow or other cause great chaos to the government's financing. We are talking about opposing revenue bills which will bring in 1 1/2 per cent at most of the government's total revenue collections this year. If any government is so incompetent, stupid and maladroit that it cannot adjust its total budget proposals to accommodate that minor reduction in its revenue intake, given that the opposition is allowing it full freedom to pass its expenditure bills—the appropriation bills—it does not deserve to be in government and I think that is the only conclusion that one can rightfully draw on this matter. There are a lot of other matters I would like to say; I look forward to leaving them to my colleagues in what will be a very vigorous and very important debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party having won an election on the impact of indirect taxes on Australian families, I find the government's decision to increase sales taxes in this package of bills now before the Senate the height of hypocrisy. Not only that, it is an exercise in gamesmanship with the Australian electorate. As my colleague Senator Short said, this government has no mandate. They are regressive taxes and it is not surprising that the government is paying the consequence of this in the opinion polls at present.

PARA.TAB: A manufacturer of electrical appliances recently wrote to us about the increase in these wholesale sales taxes. He was concerned that in these recessionary conditions it was inflationary—prices would increase. He said that the taxes would reduce consumer demand and slow down the recovery as the profit margin is not there to absorb such increases and that they would therefore be passed on with a resultant price increase to the consumer, if possible. Further, he said that this measure will increase the demand for second-hand goods on which sales tax does not apply, lessen the demand for new goods and lead to a reduction in the amount of sales tax collected. He went on to say that it will develop a black market economy dealing in cash and avoiding any payment of tax, whether sales tax or otherwise.

I would like to point out to the Senate that in the inner suburban ethnic areas of Melbourne and Sydney the boast is widespread that those people do not pay taxes. They work on the barter system. It is a boast. The PAYE earners are subsidising the black market economy and the barter system, practised by those who have closely knit communities and who can afford to barter and trade outside the Australian Taxation Office network and net.

I have often been asked: what is the status of the collection of tax when the bills have not passed the Senate and when they have not had royal assent? What will be the status of the collection of those moneys in the event of the bills not passing the Senate? As responsible members of the Senate we asked the Australian Tax Office these questions. On 21 September it responded as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the remittance of the tax goes, at this stage, due to the fact that the bills have not been passed and therefore have not received the royal assent, there is really no tax liability in existence on the rise in the sales tax rates. In actual fact, until the date of royal assent, the penalty provisions are unable to come into existence either. The net effect of that is that the due date for that tax to be returned to the tax office, provided there is passage and royal assent, is 28 days after royal assent.
It then goes on:
It has always had a date of effect of the actual date that you bring it in but effectively the law does not take over until the royal assent is received and then it has the effect of backdating.
It then goes on about the right to charge taxes before the bills have actually been passed. With respect to a supplier charging the tax, the Tax Office says:

. . . if the law does not go through, then, providing the passing-on provisions are met so the wholesaler returns the tax to the retailer, then the tax office will return the tax to the wholesaler, so the net effect is nil.
It then goes on to say:

At the retail end, it is accepted that in a situation where the Senate refused to pass a bill you would have the position that there could well be windfall gains for retailers as a result of the fact that they are not required under the law to pass the tax back. We have advised the government of this, of course, and it is a position that always sits in tax law.

Following that advice, my colleagues and I gave people the advice that they should certainly keep their documentation from retailers to ensure that they had proof that they had paid the tax in their purchase.

PARA.TAB: At present, we are examining five sales tax bills. Four of the bills will amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The fifth bill affects the rate of duty on luxury cars. The coalition is moving to oppose most of these frankly invidious and mendacious increases in the wholesale sales tax. To justify these sales tax increases, the government has drawn our attention to the fact that the indirect tax base has declined sharply over the years. I remind the Senate that the government has demonstrated a cynical, unprincipled lack of will to repair this so-called declining tax base in a fair, equitable and efficient fashion.

If we look behind the government's statement, we see that what has really happened is that the indirect taxes have increased. It is not surprising, because we have had a raft of new taxes in recent years, such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. There have been substantial increases in the fringe benefits tax. It is not surprising because, as the corporate tax came down to offset the possible movement of benefits through the corporate tax system, the government has had to substantially increase, through the fringe benefits tax regime, the tax rates. It is not surprising that the relationship between the increased collections through the income tax system, as against the indirect tax base, has widened.

I put it to the Senate that that is no excuse for the government to increase the quantum of indirect taxes in the manner in which it has. Increasing indirect sales tax in an extremely arbitrary and capricious manner does not represent a repairing of the sales tax system, as the government alleges. It represents a compounding and exacerbating of the problems that actual bedevil the system of sales tax law in Australia at present.

Dr Neil Warren has cogently articulated the view that the present system is simply incapable of meeting the fiscal demands placed upon it. It is abundantly apparent that the government's action in increasing the sales tax rate belies its words. The government may claim to acknowledge the indirect tax system's problems, but its actions are not those appropriate to such a recognition.

These indirect changes do not constitute an attempt to repair—let alone reform—the indirect tax regime. Let us not forget that these indirect tax measures have been drafted specifically to attempt to solve the problems solely of the government, problems created by the rampant dissembling that we witnessed just before the election. The fact that these tax increases fail to solve the government's problems, let alone the country's, should surprise no-one. The problem is that these tax increases are solely designed to try to pay for some of the income tax reductions which the government is trying to honour in a very backhanded way.

It is worth pointing out that, starkly contrary to the government's assertions that the promised income tax cuts were self-funding, that is, those that the government has not reneged on, will be 96 per cent funded from other higher direct and indirect taxes over the next four years. I draw the attention of the Senate to the minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in December 1992 which examined the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1992. At the hearings, we received authoritative evidence from a wide section of the Australian community that the tax cuts were unfunded. The government ignored that to its peril and that is why we have this raft of sales tax legislation, which was not announced prior to the election. That is why the government has no mandate for it. The big problem associated with these sales tax measures is that they add to cost; they cascade down through the stream of production, meaning higher costs for business, higher prices for consumers and a lower standard of living for us all.

If the government had expressly set out to destroy consumption of domestically produced wine in this country, which is another example of an horrendous tax increase, it could not have done so more effectively than with these planned sales tax increases. Honourable senators might recall that the first tax on wine was levied in about 1984 with a 10 per cent rate. The levy increased to 20 per cent in 1986. Since 1986 domestic consumption of wine has decreased from 21.6 litres per head to 17.6 litres per head.

These figures are important because the unbelievable claim that is being made is that the increase in price will have little impact on wine sales. The government does not even look at history. Unfortunately, the simple point is that when something costs more, people will pay less. The government has not looked at the price elasticity of its taxes on a product such as wine. In fact, a couple of extra dollars in price can be the difference in such a purchase being made or forgone. The reality of wine, as far as consumers are concerned, is that there are clear price ceilings.

The second fallacy that the government has been assiduously and ineffectively peddling since the budget is that increases in the sales tax on wine will not damage exports. What must be understood—you would certainly know this, Mr Acting Deputy President, coming from South Australia—is that the wineries' domestic business underwrites the export business. Without strong domestic sales there is no base for exports. Put simply, one of our most dynamic export industries has been `encouraged' by the federal government with a punitive 55 per cent increase in tax. Truly, only with this Labor government would such behaviour be thinkable—let alone implemented.

The wine industry has become internationally competitive because of quality and quality control. Significant cost savings have been achieved by wine producers through rationalisation, associated improvements in the efficiency of operation and as a result of the spreading of overheads. In spite of the significant growth of the export market, it is still the domestic market that is of prime importance to the major companies. It is the domestic market that has enabled wine companies to achieve significant economies of scale in operation to expand into the export market.

The wine tax increase immediately calls into question the investment plans of any number of wineries. Two of our largest, Penfolds and Orlando-Wyndham, have already announced reviews of their investment plans if this tax increase is to be effected.

I do not need to remind the Senate that the government's handling of the Australian economy has not been so adroit that this country can afford to forgo business investment. Indeed, when combined with state liquor licence fees, the Australian wine industry can lay claim to the dubious honour of being the most taxed in the world—and that is not a great honour.

What wineries are threatened by this increase? The larger ones will probably survive by absorbing the impost or somehow dealing with a drop in demand. However, the smaller boutique wineries which produce our most interesting and innovative wines—that is, the Australian wines that the world cannot get enough of—will unfortunately disappear. Despite the future being in premium bottled wine, it is the small wineries that will literally be destroyed by this government's desperate and insatiable search for revenue.

I read that Senator Richardson said that boutique wineries are dispensable. I put it to Senator Richardson that competitive export oriented businesses contribute more to our national wealth than we do as politicians.

What will it profit Australia if these wineries disappear, along with export incomes and the jobs that they presently provide? Is an extra $79 million in revenue worth such a trade-off? How much consideration has been given to the fact that the downturn in demand caused by the wine tax increase could well result in negative net effects on revenue?

I also wonder how much thought has been given to the damage that this measure will do to parts of regional Australia where the wine industry is based. My colleagues from South Australia, such as Senator Minchin and others, will give examples.

I will use the remaining minutes of my allotted time to speak about my state of Tasmania. The wine industry in Tasmania now has some 90 to 100 growers. This includes more than 25 fully commercial operators employing about 100 people full-time and 300 to 400 part-time and casual people. This year the local industry harvested 1,200 tonnes of grapes and produced more than one million bottles of wine.

Tasmanian wineries produce small volumes of high quality wines which are marketed at the higher end of the market. About 75 per cent of the product is sold locally and about 20 per cent is sold interstate. Currently it is estimated that only five per cent of wines produced in Tasmania are exported overseas. It needs to be remembered that in contrast to the brewing industry, which is owned multinationally and mass produces a beverage whose main raw material is water, the wine industry in my state is owned locally by Tasmanians and produces a high value added product from an intensely managed, vulnerable crop into which growers often invest their life savings.

This is but another example of the government's rhetoric being belied by its actions. The government purports to be greatly concerned with the problems faced by regional Australia. This morning we drew attention to the damage that the excise taxes will do to regional Australia, inland Australia and coastal shipping. Here is another example of a tax that will damage regional Australia.

I remind honourable senators that we have a minister for regional development, which is an echo of the Whitlam government's Fabian fantasies. But what has this government and its Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) done to save the wine industry and regional Australia? Despite the fact that we have a minister, the rhetoric is not matched by actions.

My state of Tasmania provides a marvellous example of this. Wine is perhaps Tasmania's most successful new industry. It is made up entirely of small wineries run by the very people the tax increase will hurt most. Despite Tasmania's urgent need for such business activity, my state Labor colleagues have not uttered one word in defence of their constituents, who are crying out for their help. I find it very interesting that people with normally a great deal to say on any number of topics appear to have been struck dumb on this issue.

We have seen the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) threatening the wine industry with an excise for which he claims he does not need parliamentary authority. These are blackmail tactics towards the industry. These sorts of hysterical and shrill threats are not only unbecoming of a minister of the crown; they demonstrate the Treasurer's jaundiced view of liberal democracy. The Treasurer's understanding of Australian democracy is that if people have the temerity not to agree with the government, its ministers threaten the compulsory exaction of property without legislative authority. What sort of democracy is this country sliding into? There is always pride in doing what is right. Opposing this tax increase and the sales tax on wine is a proper thing to do.

Lastly, I want briefly to address the retrospective nature of these taxes. My time has been fairly limited, but I think I have informed my listening audience, both through the broadcast and in the Senate, of the consequences if this bill is not passed. I only hope that these bills are defeated. They are dishonest in that there is no electoral mandate for them, and they will have horrific impacts on our Australian industry and on regional Australia. I hope that commonsense will prevail. I look forward to the contribution from my colleague from South Australia, Senator Minchin.

It will lose $445 million in potential vineyard, inventory and winery investment. It will lose $126 million per annum in potential export growth. Last, but certainly not least, it will lose hundreds and hundreds of jobs. This budget was going to be about jobs. What about the jobs in the wine industry; what is going to happen to them? loss of employment,—

Imposing a punitive sales tax is going to harm it. You might like to consider extrapolating our circumstances to the 600 or so other small and medium sized wineries; is this job creation? Is this encouraging small business? Is this helping Australia's trade deficit? Is this in fact the Tall Poppy syndrome as practised by the Federal Treasury?

The Australian wine industry is one of the few showing strong export growth. This cannot be sustained without a strong and stable domestic base. The enormous increase in the sales tax bill will reduce domestic sales and decrease profitability. This will deter investment in the industry, cause extensive labour force reductions and send some small businesses out of production. This is hardly the recipe for continued export expansion. Furthermore, higher prices at the top of the market will increase competition from imports, often mistakenly seen as quality products. Increased sales of imported wines will tend to nullify the balance of payments effect of forcing an increase in (sales tax free) wine exports. Incidentally, the increased revenue supposedly derived from this new sales tax level is intended to cover the cost of some generous export support schemes offered to our major companies—a rather dubious quid pro quo.

The 1993 budget proposal to increase sales tax on wine by 55% is counter-productive; it threatens the livelihood of all small wineries, and encourages the concentration of the industry into even fewer major companies who have the means to minimise sales tax liability and who have large enough export operations to qualify for the export support schemes funded by the Federal Government. The result may well be a decrease in the net revenue collected from this source. I ask you to use your influence and political judgement to enforce a rethink by our Treasurer, having the capacity to impose amendments to the budget proposals in the Senate.
Yours sincerely

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) If there is a need for Customs to conduct strip searches at international airports.
(2) For each country, how many people of overseas origin who have passed through Customs over the past 5 years have been strip searched.

(3) Under the categories of close family, business, tourist, medical and other visitors, pleast list how many any of those who were strip searched were: (a) on short stay visas; (b) on visitor visas; and (c) migrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) On 24 April 1991, the Customs (Detention and Search) Act 1990, commonly known as the `frisk' legislation came into effect after passing through Parliament with strong support from both the Government and the Opposition.

The new legislation which authorised a more comprehensive range of detention and search powers for both Customs and Police, was in response to public concern at the increasing dangers of illegal drug importations and strong evidence of an increasing trend to bring drugs into the country concealed on the body. In 1992/93, in-bound travelling airline passengers accounted for some 15% of all drugs seized by the ACS.

A feature of the current legislation is that it expressly provides protection, rights and obligations for both suspects and officers alike. In addition, Customs' operating directions and procedures for personal search are designed to reflect a reasonable balance between preserving a person's dignity and liberty and the protection of the community as a whole.

The Australian Customs Service (ACS) has a very difficult job in exercising its control function to detect those persons intent on deliberately circumventing the laws of Australia designed for the protection of the community and the economy. It is an unfortunate fact that some people will use almost any means imaginable to import prohibited goods into Australia. This means that sometimes Customs is obliged to carry out a personal search to confirm that a person is not concealing any such goods on their body.

The ACS is acutely aware of the sensitivity of its legislative powers to detain a person for personal search and does not take its responsibilities lightly. Its officers are trained to ensure that all examinations undertaken are both necessary and thorough. Personal searches are not conducted on a routine or random basis. A detention officer must have reasonable grounds for his/her suspicions and there are strict procedures in place that respect a person's rights.

In general terms, the basis for selection includes such things as a person's travel itinerary, answers to question, documents in possession, unusual behaviour and the contents or appearance of the person's baggage. These grounds are in accordance with the detention and search provisions of the Customs Act.

(2) Personal search records are maintained in strict accordance with the information privacy principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988. Database systems which assist with enforcement profiling do not identify any personal details for "nil" result searches. The ACS does maintain a "Register of Persons Searched" at each airport. It is a strictly confidential document and access to information it contains by outside agencies or persons is subject to the confidentiality provisions of the Customs Administration Act and the Privacy Act. This register does not record a person's nationality, visa details or what was their purpose for travel. I am therefore unable to provide detailed answers to either this or part (3) of the Senator's question.
(3) See (2) above.
